```{r 4.45}
# Height in centimeters (vertical) plotted against weight in kilograms (horizontal), 
# with the maximum a posteriori (MAP) line for the mean height at each weight plotted in black.

```

<br>

#### Adding uncertainty around the mean

The posterior distribution considers every possible regression line connecting height to weight. It assigns a relative plausibility to each. This means that each combination of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\alpha}" title="" /> and <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\beta}" title="" /> has a posterior probability. It could be that there are many lines with nearly the same posterior probability as the MAP line. Or it could be instead that the posterior distribution is rather narrow near the MAP line.

So how can we get that uncertainty onto the plot? Together, a combination of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\alpha}" title="" /> and <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\beta}" title="" /> define a line. And so we could sample a bunch of lines from the posterior distribution. Then we could display those lines on the plot, to visualize the uncertainty in the regression relationship.

```{r 4.46}

# To better appreciate how the posterior distribution contains lines, extract some samples from the model
post <- extract.samples(m4.3)

# Inspect the first 5 rows of the samples
post[1:5,]

```

<br>

Each row is a correlated random sample from the joint posterior of all three parameters, using the covariances provided by vcov(m4.3). The paired values of a and b on each row define a line. The average of very many of these lines is the MAP line. But the scatter around that average is meaningful, because it alters our confidence in the relationship between the predictor and the outcome.

```{r 4.48}

# extracts the first 10 cases and re-estimates the model
N <- 10
dN <- d2[1:N, ]
mN <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    height ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + b*weight,
    a ~ dnorm(178, 100),
    b ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 50)
  ), data = dN
)

# plot 20 of these lines, to see what the uncertainty looks like
# extract 20 samples from the posterior
post <- extract.samples(mN, n = 20)

# display raw data and sample size
plot(dN$weight, dN$height,
     xlim = range(d2$weight), ylim = range(d2$height),
     col = rangi2, xlab = "weight", ylab = "height")
mtext(concat("N = ", N)) # add text to the plot indicating sample size

# plot the lines with transparency
# i-th sample is a set of random parameter values sampled from posterior distribution
for (i in 1:20) # loops over all 20 lines, using abline to display each
  abline(a = post$a[i], b = post$b[i], col = col.alpha("black", 0.3))

# The cloud of regression lines displays greater uncertainty at extreme values for weight. 
# This is very common.

```

<br>

```{r 4.48.1}

# compare higher N values (bigger sample size)

par(mfrow = c(2,2), mar = c(4,4,4,4))

# 20 samples
## show error in knitting if I use 10 sample here, although it works above with warning
## 10 samples is too low to reach stable estimates
N0 <- 20
dN0 <- d2[1:N0, ]
mN0 <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    height ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + b*weight,
    a ~ dnorm(178, 100),
    b ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 50)
  ), data = dN0
)

post0 <- extract.samples(mN0, n = 20)

plot(dN0$weight, dN0$height,
     xlim = range(d2$weight), ylim = range(d2$height),
     col = rangi2, xlab = "weight", ylab = "height")
mtext(concat("N = ", N0)) 

for (i in 1:20) 
  abline(a = post0$a[i], b = post0$b[i], col = col.alpha("black", 0.3))


# 50 samples
N1 = 50
dN1 <- d2[1:N1, ]
mN1 <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    height ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + b*weight ,
        a ~ dnorm( 178 , 100 ) ,
        b ~ dnorm( 0 , 10 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 50 )
  ), data = dN1
)

post1 <- extract.samples( mN1, n=20)

plot( dN1$weight , dN1$height ,
    xlim=range(d2$weight) , ylim=range(d2$height) ,
    col=rangi2 , xlab="weight" , ylab="height" )
mtext(concat("N = ",N1))

for ( i in 1:20 )
    abline( a=post1$a[i] , b=post1$b[i] , col=col.alpha("black",0.3) )

# 150 samples
N2 = 150
dN2 <- d2[1:N2, ]
mN2 <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    height ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + b*weight ,
        a ~ dnorm( 178 , 100 ) ,
        b ~ dnorm( 0 , 10 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 50 )
  ), data = dN2
)

post2 <- extract.samples( mN2, n=20 )

plot( dN2$weight , dN2$height ,
    xlim=range(d2$weight) , ylim=range(d2$height) ,
    col=rangi2 , xlab="weight" , ylab="height" )
mtext(concat("N = ",N2))

for ( i in 1:20 )
    abline( a=post2$a[i] , b=post2$b[i] , col=col.alpha("black",0.3) )

# 352 samples
N3 = 352
dN3 <- d2[1:N3, ]
mN3 <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    height ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + b*weight ,
        a ~ dnorm( 178 , 100 ) ,
        b ~ dnorm( 0 , 10 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 50 )
  ), data = dN3
)

post3 <- extract.samples( mN3, n=20 )

plot( dN3$weight , dN3$height ,
    xlim=range(d2$weight) , ylim=range(d2$height) ,
    col=rangi2 , xlab="weight" , ylab="height" )
mtext(concat("N = ",N3))

for ( i in 1:20 )
    abline( a=post3$a[i] , b=post3$b[i] , col=col.alpha("black",0.3) )

# The cloud of regression lines grows more compact as the sample size increases. 
# This is a result of the model growing more confident about the location of the mean.

```

<br>

#### Plotting regression intervals and contours

It’s much more common to see the uncertainty displayed by plotting an interval or contour around the MAP regression line, than a cloud of regression lines. 

```{r 4.50}

# Example:

# See the vector
post_test <- extract.samples(mN, n = 20)
mu_at_40 <- post_test$a + post_test$b * 40
mu_at_40
# It’s a vector of predicted means, one for each random sample from the posterior. 
# Since joint a and b went into computing each, the variation across those means 
# incorporates the uncertainty in and correlation between both parameters.

# make a list of 10,000 values of μ for an individual who weighs 50 kilograms, 
# by using samples from the posterior (μ_i = α + βx_i)
post <- extract.samples(mN, n = 1e4)
mu_at_50 <- post$a + post$b * 50 # value of x_i is 50 in this case

post3 <- extract.samples(mN3, n = 1e4)
mu_at_50_3 <- post3$a + post3$b * 50

# Plot the density for the vector of means
par(mfrow = c(1,2))
dens(mu_at_50, col = rangi2, lwd = 2, xlab = "mu|weight = 50 (10 samples)")
dens(mu_at_50_3, col = rangi2, lwd = 2, xlab = "mu|weight = 50 (352 samples)")
# The quadratic approximate posterior distribution of the mean height, μ, when 
# weight is 50 kg. This distribution represents the relative plausibility of 
# different values of the mean.

```

<br>

Since the posterior for <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu}" title="" /> is a distribution, you can find intervals for it, just like for any posterior distribution. To find the 89% highest posterior density interval of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu}" title="" /> at 50 kg, just use the HPDI command as usual:

```{r 4.52}

HPDI(mu_at_50, prob = 0.89)
# Wider interval of distribution (more uncertainty) with low number of observed data.

HPDI(mu_at_50_3, prob = 0.89)
# The central 89% of the ways for the model to produce the data place the average 
# height between about 159 cm and 160 cm (conditional on the model and data), 
# assuming the weight is 50 kg.

```

<br>

We need to repeat the above calculation for every weight value on the horizontal axis, not just when it is 50 kg. We want to draw 89% HPDIs around the MAP slope. This can be done by using `link` function. What `link` will do is take your `map` model fit, sample from the posterior distribution, and then compute <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu}" title="" /> for each case in the data and sample from the posterior distribution.

```{r 4.53}

mu <- link(m4.3)
str(mu) # to compactly show data frame
# You end up with a big matrix of values of μ. Each row is a sample from the posterior distribution. 
# The default is 1000 samples, but you can use as many or as few as you like. 
# Each column is a case (row) in the data. There are 352 rows in d2, corresponding 
# to 352 individuals. So there are 352 columns in the matrix mu above.
```

<br>

Now we have a distribution of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu}" title="" /> for each individual in the original data. We actually want something slightly different: a distribution of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu}" title="" /> for each unique weight value on the horizontal axis.

```{r 4.54}

# define sequence of weights to compute predictions for
# these values will be on the horizontal axis
weight.seq <- seq( from=25 , to=70 , by=1 )

# use link to compute mu
# for each sample from posterior
# and for each weight in weight.seq
mu <- link( m4.3 , data=data.frame(weight=weight.seq) )

str(mu)
# Now there are only 46 columns in mu, because we fed it 46 different values for weight.

# Plot the distribution of μ values at each height
# use type="n" to hide raw data
plot( height ~ weight , d2 , type="n" )

# loop over samples and plot each mu value
for ( i in 1:100 )
    points( weight.seq , mu[i,] , pch=16 , col=col.alpha(rangi2,0.1) )
# The first 100 values in the distribution of μ at each weight value.
# At each weight value in weight.seq, a pile of computed μ values are shown. 
# Each of these piles is a Gaussian distribution. You can see now that the amount 
# of uncertainty in μ depends upon the value of weight.

## The final step is to summarize the distribution for each weight value.
# summarize the distribution of mu
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean ) # 2 is columns, 1 is rows
mu.mean
# Read apply(mu,2,mean) as compute the mean of each column (dimension “2”) of the matrix mu. 
# mu.mean contains the average μ at each weight value.

mu.HPDI <- apply( mu , 2 , HPDI , prob=0.89 )
mu.HPDI
# mu.HPDI contains 89% lower and upper bounds for each weight value.

## You can plot these summaries on top of the data with a few lines of R code:
# plot raw data
# fading out points to make line and interval more visible
plot( height ~ weight , data=d2 , col=col.alpha(rangi2,0.5) )

# plot the MAP line, aka the mean mu for each weight
lines( weight.seq , mu.mean )

# plot a shaded region for 89% HPDI
shade( mu.HPDI , weight.seq )
# The !Kung height data again, now with 89% HPDI of the mean indicated by the shaded region.
# The confidence interval for the regression line clings tightly to the MAP line. Thus there is 
# very little uncertainty about the average height as a function of average weight. But you have
# to keep in mind that these inferences are always conditional on the model. Even a very bad model 
# can have very tight confidence intervals. It may help if you think of the regression line as: 
# Conditional on the assumption that height and weight are related by a straight line, then this is 
# the most plausible line, and these are its plausible bounds.

## Compare this region to the distributions of blue points on the left.
par(mfrow = c(1,2))

plot( height ~ weight , d2 , type="n" )
for ( i in 1:100 )
    points( weight.seq , mu[i,] , pch=16 , col=col.alpha(rangi2,0.1) )

plot( height ~ weight , data=d2 , col=col.alpha(rangi2,0.5) )
lines( weight.seq , mu.mean )
shade( mu.HPDI , weight.seq )

```

<br>

<span style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Recipe for generating predictions and intervals from the posterior of a fit model**</span></span>

(1) Use `link` to generate distributions of posterior values for <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu}" title="" />. The default behavior of `link` is to use the original data, so you have to pass it a list of new horizontal axis values you want to plot posterior predictions across.

(2) Use summary functions like `mean` or `HPDI` or `PI` to find averages and lower and upper bounds of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu}" title="" /> for each value of the predictor variable.

(3) Finally, use plotting functions like `lines` and `shade` to draw the lines and intervals. Or you might plot the distributions of the predictions, or do further numerical calculations with them. It’s really up to you.

<br>

<span style="color:purple">***Manual method for using `link`:***</span>

```{r 4.58}

# extract samples from the fitted model
post <- extract.samples(m4.3)

# Predict mu based on weight using linear function
mu.link <- function(weight) post$a + post$b*weight

# Define sequence of weights, with increment of 1, to compute predictions
# This clears the repetition in weights?
weight.seq <- seq( from=25 , to=70 , by=1 )

# For each value in weight.seq, calculate corresponding mu values based on the linear
# prediction function mu.link
mu <- sapply( weight.seq , mu.link )

# Calculate a vector of mean mu and HPDI for each column (each sample) of mu
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
mu.HPDI <- apply( mu , 2 , HPDI , prob=0.89 )

# The values in mu.mean and mu.HPDI should be very similar (allowing for 
# simulation variance) to what you got the automated way, using link.
mu.mean
mu.HPDI

```

<br>

#### Prediction intervals

Now let's generate an 89% prediction interval for actual heights, not just the average height, <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu}" title="" /> by incorporating the standard deviation <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\sigma}" title="" /> and its uncertainty as well. 

Imagine simulating heights. For any unique weight value, you sample from a Gaussian distribution with the correct mean <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu}" title="" /> for that weight, using the correct value of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\sigma}" title="" /> sampled from the same posterior distribution. If you do this for every sample from the posterior, for every weight value of interest, you end up with a collection of simulated heights that embody the uncertainty in the posterior as well as the uncertainty in the Gaussian likelihood.

```{r 4.59}

sim.height <- sim(m4.3, data = list(weight = weight.seq))

str(sim.height)
# This matrix is much like the earlier one, mu, but it contains simulated heights, 
# not distributions of plausible average height, μ.

# summarize these simulated heights in the same way we summarized the distributions of μ, 
# by using apply
height.PI <- apply(sim.height, 2, PI, prob = 0.89)
height.PI
# Now height.PI contains the 89% posterior prediction interval of observable 
# (according to the model) heights, across the values of weight in weight.seq.

## Plot everything we’ve built up: (1) the MAP line, (2) the shaded region of 89% plausible μ, 
## and (3) the boundaries of the simulated heights the model expects
# plot raw data
plot( height ~ weight , d2 , col=col.alpha(rangi2,0.5) )

# draw MAP line
lines( weight.seq , mu.mean )

# draw HPDI region for line
shade( mu.HPDI , weight.seq )

# draw PI region for simulated heights
shade( height.PI , weight.seq )
# 89% prediction interval for height, as a function of weight. The solid line is 
# the MAP estimate of the mean height at each weight. The two shaded regions show 
# different 89% plausible regions. The narrow shaded interval around the line is 
# the distribution of μ. The wider shaded region represents the region within which 
# the model expects to find 89% of actual heights in the population, at each weight.
```

<br>

Notice that the outline for the wide shaded interval is a little jagged. This is the simulation variance in the tails of the sampled Gaussian values. If it really bothers you, increase the number of samples you take from the posterior distribution. The optional n parameter for sim.height controls how many samples are used.

```{r 4.62}

# Increase samples for simulation
sim.height <- sim(m4.3, data = list(weight = weight.seq), n = 1e4)
height.PI <- apply(sim.height, 2, PI, prob = 0.89)

# Plot the PI again
plot( height ~ weight , d2 , col=col.alpha(rangi2,0.5) )
lines( weight.seq , mu.mean )
shade( mu.HPDI , weight.seq )
shade( height.PI , weight.seq )

```

<br>

<span style="color:purple">***Compare 67% and 97% intervals***</span>

```{r 67.97}

par(mfrow = c(1,2))

# Simulate height
sim.height <- sim(m4.3, data = list(weight = weight.seq))
                  
# Plot for 67%
height.PI <- apply(sim.height, 2, PI, prob = 0.67)
plot(height ~ weight, d2, col = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.5), main = "67% interval")
lines(weight.seq, mu.mean)
shade(mu.HPDI, weight.seq)
shade(height.PI, weight.seq)

# Plot for 97%
height.PI <- apply(sim.height, 2, PI, prob = 0.97)
plot(height ~ weight, d2, col = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.5), main = "97% interval")
lines(weight.seq, mu.mean)
shade(mu.HPDI, weight.seq)
shade(height.PI, weight.seq)

```

<br>

<span style="color:purple">***Manual method for using `sim`:***</span>

For every distribution like `dnorm`, there is a companion simulation function. For the Gaussian distribution, the companion is `rnorm`, and it simulates sampling from a Gaussian distribution. What we want R to do is simulate a height for each set of samples, and to do this for each value of weight.

```{r 4.63}

# Extract posterior or prior samples from map model
post <- extract.samples(m4.3) # default n = 1e4

# Define weight sequence
weight.seq <- 25:70

# Simulate height 
sim.height <- sapply( weight.seq , function(weight)
    rnorm( # use rnorm to generate random normal values based on the parameters
        n=nrow(post) ,
        mean=post$a + post$b*weight ,
        sd=post$sigma ) )

# Calculate predicted interval of height
height.PI <- apply( sim.height , 2 , PI , prob=0.89 )
height.PI
# The values in height.PI will be practically identical to the ones computed above for 89%.

```

<br>

## Polynomial regression

It helps to see how to model the outcome as a curved function of a single predictor. The models so far all assume that a straight line describes the relationship. But there’s nothing special about straight lines, aside from their simplicity.

```{r 4.64}

# Load data
data("Howell1")

# Create data set d including all data 
d <- Howell1
str(d)

# Plot d
plot(height ~ weight, d, col = col.alpha("black", 0.5))
# The relationship is visibly curved, now that we’ve included the non-adult individuals.

```

<br>

Polynomial regression is one of the ways to model a curved relationship between two variables. In this context, “polynomial” means equations for <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu_i}" title="" /> that add additional terms with squares, cubes, and even higher powers of the predictor variable. There’s still only one predictor variable in the model, so this is still a bivariate regression. But the definition of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu_i}" title="" /> has more parameters now.

The most common polynomial regression, a parabolic model of the mean:

![](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\boldsymbol{\mu_i = \alpha + \beta_1 x_i + \beta_2 x_i^2})
<br>

The above is a parabolic (second order) polynomial. The <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\alpha + \beta_1 x_i}" title="" /> part is the same linear function of x in a linear regression, just with a little “1” subscript added to the parameter name, so we can tell it apart from the new parameter. The additional term uses the square of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{x_i}" title="" /> to construct a parabola, rather than a perfectly straight line. The new parameter <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\beta_2}" title="" /> measures the curvature of the relationship.

The parabolic model of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu_i}" title="" /> above is still called a “linear model” of the mean. What “linear” usually means in this context is that <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu_i}" title="" /> is a linear function of any single parameter. 

<br>

### Fitting the model to data

The first thing to do is to standardize the predictor variable. This means to first center the variable and then divide it by its standard deviation.

```{r 4.65}

# Subtract the mean and then divide by the standard deviation to standardize weight
d$weight.s <- (d$weight - mean(d$weight))/ sd(d$weight)
# This new variable weight.s has mean zero and standard deviation 1.

# Plot the standardized data to verify no information has been lost
plot(height ~ weight.s, d, col = col.alpha("black", 0.5))
# The same curved relationship as before, but now with a different range on the horizontal axis.

```

<br>

<span style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Parabolic regression**</span></span>

To fit the parabolic model, just modify the definition of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu_i}" title="" />. Here’s the model (with very weak priors):

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}h_i&\sim&space;Normal(\mu_i,\sigma)&&&height&\sim&space;dnorm(mu,sigma)\\\mu_i&=\alpha&plus;\beta_1x_i&plus;\beta_2x_i^2&&&mu&\leftarrow&space;a&plus;b1\times&space;weight.s&plus;b2\times&space;weight.s^2\\\alpha&\sim&space;Normal(178,100)&&&a&\sim&space;dnorm(178,100)\\\beta_1&\sim&space;Normal(0,10)&&&b1&\sim&space;dnorm(0,10)\\\beta_2&\sim&space;Normal(0,10)&&&b2&\sim&space;dnorm(0,10)\\\sigma&\sim&space;Uniform(0,50)&&&sigma&\sim&space;dunif(0,50)\\\end{align*}" title="\begin{align*}h_i&\sim Normal(\mu_i,\sigma)&&&height&\sim dnorm(mu,sigma)\\\mu_i&=\alpha+\beta_1x_i+\beta_2x_i^2&&&mu&\leftarrow a+b1\times weight.s+b2\times weight.s^2\\\alpha&\sim Normal(178,100)&&&a&\sim dnorm(178,100)\\\beta_1&\sim Normal(0,10)&&&b1&\sim dnorm(0,10)\\\beta_2&\sim Normal(0,10)&&&b2&\sim dnorm(0,10)\\\sigma&\sim Uniform(0,50)&&&sigma&\sim dunif(0,50)\\\end{align*}}" />

<br>

```{r 4.66}

# Build the square weight.s as separate variable
d$weight.s2 <- d$weight.s^2

# Fit the model by modifying the definition of mu so that it contains 
# both the ordinary and quadratic terms
m4.5 <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    height ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + b1*weight.s + b2*weight.s2,
    a ~ dnorm(178, 100),
    b1 ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    b2 ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 50)
  ), 
  data = d
)

# Summarize the map model
precis(m4.5)
# The parameter α (a) is still the intercept, so it tells us the expected value of height 
# when weight.s is zero. But it is no longer equal to the mean height in the sample, 
# since there is no guarantee it should in a polynomial regression.
# β1 and β2 parameters are the linear and square components of the curve, respectively.

## Plot the model fits
# Calculate the mean relationship and the 89% intervals of the mean and the predictions
# Define predictor values for weight
weight.seq <- seq( from=-2.2 , to=2 , length.out=30 )

# Create a list with weight.s and weight.s2 values (pre-calculation)
pred_dat <- list( weight.s=weight.seq , weight.s2=weight.seq^2 )

# Calculate predicted mu values based on model m4.5 using predictor values in pred_dat
mu <- link( m4.5 , data=pred_dat )

# Calculate mean of predicted mu values across columns
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )

# Calculate prediction interval with prob 89% of the predicted mu values
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI , prob=0.89 )

# Simulate height values based on model m4.5 using predictor values in pred_dat
sim.height <- sim( m4.5 , data=pred_dat )

# Calculate prediction interval for simulated heights with prob 89%
height.PI <- apply( sim.height , 2 , PI , prob=0.89 )

# Plot MAP, PI of predicted means and PI of simulated heights
# Plot raw data
plot( height ~ weight.s , d , col=col.alpha(rangi2,0.5) )

# Add map line
lines( weight.seq , mu.mean )

# Shade prediction interval for mu values
shade( mu.PI , weight.seq )

# Shade prediction interval for simulated heights
shade( height.PI , weight.seq )
# The curve does a much better job of finding a central path through the data, than 
# the linear model. 


```

<br>

<span style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Cubic regression**</span></span>

The model is (hiding the priors, but they are the same as before):

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}h_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_1 x_i + \beta_2 x_i^2 + \beta_3 x_i^3\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

Fit the model with a slight modification of the parabolic model’s code:

```{r 4.70}

# Create a separate variable for cubic weight
d$weight.s3 <- d$weight.s^3

# Fit the map model
m4.6 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        height ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + b1*weight.s + b2*weight.s2 + b3*weight.s3 ,
        a ~ dnorm( 178 , 100 ) ,
        b1 ~ dnorm( 0 , 10 ) ,
        b2 ~ dnorm( 0 , 10 ) ,
        b3 ~ dnorm( 0 , 10 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 50 )
), data=d )

# Summarize the map model
precis(m4.6)

# Define predictor values for weight
weight.seq <- seq(from = -2.2, to = 2, length.out = 30)

# Create a list with weight.s, weight.s2 and weight.s3 values
pred_dat_c <- list(weight.s = weight.seq, weight.s2 = weight.seq^2, weight.s3 = weight.seq^3)

# Calculate predicted mu values for based on model and predictor values
mu_c <- link(m4.6, data = pred_dat_c)

# Calculate mean of predicted mu values across column
mu.mean_c <- apply(mu_c, 2, mean)

# Calculate PI of predicted mu values (89% interval)
mu.PI_c <- apply(mu_c, 2, PI, prob = 0.89)

# Simulate height values based on model and predictor values
sim.height_c <- sim(m4.6, data = pred_dat_c)

# Calculate PI of simulated heights
height.PI_c <- apply(sim.height_c, 2, PI, prob = 0.89)

# Plot raw data
plot(height ~ weight.s, d, col = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.5))

# Add map line
lines(weight.seq, mu.mean_c)

# Shade PI for mu values
shade(mu.PI_c, weight.seq)

# Shade PI of simulated heights
shade(height.PI_c, weight.seq)
# This cubic curve is even more flexible than the parabola, so it fits the data even better.

```

<br>

<span style="color:purple">***Compare linear, parabolic and cubic regressions***</span>

```{r regression}

par(mfrow = c(1,3))

# Plot the linear regression
m4_l <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    height ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + b*weight.s,
    a ~ dnorm(178, 100),
    b ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 50)
  ),
  data = d
)
precis(m4_l)

weight.seq <- seq(from = -2.2, to = 2, length.out = 30)
pred_dat_l <- list(weight.s = weight.seq)
mu_l <- link(m4_l, data = pred_dat_l)
mu.mean_l <- apply(mu_l, 2, mean)
mu.PI_l <- apply(mu_l, 2, PI, prob = 0.89)
sim.height_l <- sim(m4_l, data = pred_dat_l)
height.PI_l <- apply(sim.height_l, 2, PI, prob = 0.89)
plot(height ~ weight.s, d, col = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.5), main = "(a)")
lines(weight.seq, mu.mean_l)
shade(mu.PI_l, weight.seq)
shade(height.PI_l, weight.seq)

# Plot the parabolic regression
plot( height ~ weight.s , d , col=col.alpha(rangi2,0.5), main = "(b)")
lines( weight.seq , mu.mean )
shade( mu.PI , weight.seq )
shade( height.PI , weight.seq )

# Plot the cubic regression
plot(height ~ weight.s, d, col = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.5), main = "(c)")
lines(weight.seq, mu.mean_c)
shade(mu.PI_c, weight.seq)
shade(height.PI_c, weight.seq)

# Polynomial regressions of height on weight (standardized),for the full !Kung data. 
# In each plot, the raw data are shown by the circles. The solid curves show the path 
# of μ in each model, and the shaded regions show the 89% interval of the mean (close to 
# the solid curve) and the 89% interval of predictions (wider). 
# (a) Linear regression. (b) A second order polynomial, a parabolic regression. 
# (c) A third order polynomial, a cubic regression.

```

<br>

<span style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Converting back to natural scale**</span>

The three plots above have standard units on the horizontal axis. These units are sometimes called z-scores. But suppose you fit the model using standardized variables, but want to plot the estimates on the original scale. All that’s really needed is first to turn off the horizontal axis when you plot the raw data:

```{r 4.71}

## Turn off the horizontal axis using xaxt (x-axis shouldn't be plotted- to plot manually)
plot(height ~ weight.s, d, col = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.5), xaxt = "n") # n = none

## Construct the axis, using axis function
# Defines location of the labels, in standardized units
at <- c(-2,-1,0,1,2)

# Convert those units back to the original scale
labels <- at*sd(d$weight) + mean(d$weight)

# Draw the axis                     # round the labels to 1 decimal place
axis(side = 1 , at = at , labels = round(labels,1)) # 1=below, 2=left, 3=above, 4=right

```

<br>

## Practice

### Easy

<br>

4E1. <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{y_i \sim Normal(\mu, \sigma)}" title="" />

<br>

4E2. two parameters: mu and sigma

<br>

4E3. <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{Pr(\mu, \sigma|y) = \frac{Normal(y|\mu,\sigma) Normal(\mu|0,10) Uniform(\sigma|0,10) }{\int \int Normal(y|\mu,\sigma) Normal(\mu|0,10) Uniform(\sigma|0,10)d\mu d\sigma}}" title="" />

<br>

4E4. ![](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\boldsymbol{\mu_i = \alpha + \beta x_i})

<br>

4E5. three parameters: alpha, beta and sigma

<br>

### Medium

4M1. 

```{r 4M1}

# Generate samples for mu
sample_mu <- rnorm(1e4, 0, 10)

# Generate samples for sigma
sample_sigma <- runif(1e4, 0, 10)

# Simulate heights from prior
prior_height <- rnorm(1e4, sample_mu, sample_sigma)

# Plot heights
dens(prior_height)

```

<br>

4M2.
```{r 4M2}

data("Howell1")
d <- Howell1
d2 <- d[d$age >= 18, ]


m.4m2 <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    height ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
    ),
  data = d2
) 

precis(m.4m2)
```

<br>

4M3. 
<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}y_i &\sim Normal(\mu, \sigma)\\\mu &= \alpha + \beta x_i\\\alpha &\sim Normal(0, 50)\\\beta &\sim Normal(0, 10)\\\sigma &\sim Uniform(0, 50)\\\end{align*}" title="" />


<br>

4M4. We don't know the age and gender of students. So, we will use uninformative priors, inclusive school age children to adult. 200 is chosen considering the adult height (may not be necessary?) and mean <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\beta}" title="" /> is zero considering height will not increase if the students are adult, but <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\sigma}" title="" /> is 40 to leave room for potential increase in height. 

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}h_i &\sim Normal(\mu, \sigma)\\\mu &= \alpha + \beta y_i\\\alpha &\sim Normal(0, 200)\\\beta &\sim Normal(0, 40)\\\sigma &\sim Uniform(0, 50)\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

4M5. Since average age is 120 cm, we will assume the students are around 7 years old, and estimate annual growth at 6-7 cm per year based on literature. 

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}h_i &\sim Normal(\mu, \sigma)\\\mu &= \alpha + \beta y_i\\\alpha &\sim Normal(120, 20)\\\beta &\sim Normal(6, 10)\\\sigma &\sim Uniform(0, 30)\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

4M6. If the variance  among heights for students of the same age is never more than 64cm:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}h_i &\sim Normal(\mu, \sigma)\\\mu &= \alpha + \beta y_i\\\alpha &\sim Normal(120, 20)\\\beta &\sim Normal(6, 10)\\\sigma &\sim Uniform(0, 64)\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

### Hard

> 4H1. The weights listed below were recorded in the !Kung census, but heights were not recorded for these individuals. Provide predicted heights and 89% intervals (either HPDI or PI) for each of these individuals.

```{r 4H1}

# Create map model
data("Howell1")
d <- Howell1
mN <- rethinking::map(
  alist( 
     height ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
        mu <- a + b*weight,
        a ~ dnorm(120, 20),
        b ~ dnorm(6, 10),
        sigma ~ dunif(0, 64)
  ), 
  
  data = d
)

precis(mN)

# Extract samples from map model
post <- extract.samples(mN, n = 1e5)

# For individual1 with weight 46.95
mu_at_46.95 <- post$a + post$b * 46.95
dens(mu_at_46.95, xlab = "mu|weight = 46.95")
mean(mu_at_46.95)
HPDI(mu_at_46.95, prob = 0.89)

# For individual2 with weight 43.72
mu_at_43.72 <- post$a + post$b * 43.72
dens(mu_at_43.72, xlab = "mu|weight = 43.72")
mean(mu_at_43.72)
HPDI(mu_at_43.72, prob = 0.89)

# For individual3 with weight 64.78
mu_at_64.78 <- post$a + post$b * 64.78
dens(mu_at_64.78, xlab = "mu|weight = 64.78")
mean(mu_at_64.78)
HPDI(mu_at_64.78, prob = 0.89)

# For individual4 with weight 32.59
mu_at_32.59 <- post$a + post$b * 32.59
dens(mu_at_32.59, xlab = "mu|weight = 32.59")
mean(mu_at_32.59)
HPDI(mu_at_32.59, prob = 0.89)

# For individual5 with weight 54.63
mu_at_54.63 <- post$a + post$b * 54.63
dens(mu_at_54.63, xlab = "mu|weight = 54.63")
mean(mu_at_54.63)
HPDI(mu_at_54.63, prob = 0.89)

```

<br>

<span style ="color:purple">***Given Answer:***</span>

```{r 3.4}

# First, fit the model with map, to provide a quadratic approximation of the posterior. 
# I’ll use quite flat priors here, but if you used stronger priors, that’s fine. 
# What matters is the procedure be coherent.
data(Howell1)
d <- Howell1
d2 <- d[d$age>=18,]
m <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        height ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + b*weight ,
        a ~ dnorm( 100 , 100 ) ,
        b ~ dnorm( 0 , 10 ) ,
sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 50 ) ),
data=d2 )

# Then produce samples from the quadratic approximate posterior. You could use mvrnorm directly, 
# or the convenient extract.samples function:
post <- extract.samples( m )
str(post)

# Now we want to plug the weights in the table into this model, and then average over 
# the posterior to compute predictions for each individual’s height. The question is ambiguous 
# as to whether it wants μ only or rather the distribution of individual height measurements 
# (using σ). I’ll show the harder approach, that uses σ and simulates individual heights. 
# Also, I won’t use link or sim, but it’s fine if you did.

# For the first individual, the code might look like this:
y <- rnorm( 1e5 , post$a + post$b*46.95 , post$sigma )
mean(y)
HPDI(y,prob=0.90)

# How does the code work? The first line, which includes rnorm, simulates 100-thousand heights, 
# using the samples from the posterior and an assumed weight of 46.95 kg. The second line then 
# computes the average of these simulated heights. That gives the expected (mean) height. 
# The third line then computes the 90% HPDI of height.
# You could have also computed the expected heights straight from the MAP. 
# That approach is fine, and will give nearly the same answer.

```

<br>

> 4H2. Select out all the rows in the Howell1 data with ages below 18 years of age. If you do it right, you should end up with a new data frame with 192 rows in it.

```{r 4H2}

# Select out all the rows in the Howell1 data with ages below 18 years of age
data("Howell1")
d <- Howell1
d2 <- d[d$age < 18, ]
str(d2)

## (a) Fit a linear regression to these data, using map. Present and interpret the estimates. 
## For every 10 units of increase in weight, how much taller does the model predict a child gets?

# Fit a linear regression using map
mN <- rethinking::map(
  alist( 
     height ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
        mu <- a + b*weight,
        a ~ dnorm(120, 20),
        b ~ dnorm(6, 10),
        sigma ~ dunif(0, 64)
  ), 
  
  data = d2
)

precis(mN)

# The model predicts the child's height at 58.53 cm when the predictor value is zero.
# Every 1 unit increase in weight, the model predicts 2.71 cm increase in height.
# So, height will be increased by 27.1 cm (sd = 0.07) for every 10 units increase in weight. 

## (b) Plot the raw data, with height on the vertical axis and weight on the horizontal axis. 
## Superimpose the MAP regression line and 89% HPDI for the mean. Also superimpose the 
## 89% HPDI for predicted heights.

# Compute mu for each chase in data and sample for posterior distribution
post <- extract.samples(mN)
mu.link <- function(weight) post$a + post$b*weight
weight.seq <- seq(from = 0, to = 50, by = 1)
mu <- sapply(weight.seq, mu.link)
str(mu)

# Compute mean and HPDI of mu 
mu.mean <- apply(mu, 2, mean)
mu.HPDI <- apply(mu, 2, HPDI, prob = 0.89)

# Plot the raw data
plot(height ~ weight, d2, col = col.alpha("red", 0.4))

# Add map line
lines(weight.seq, mu.mean)

# Shade 89% HDPI
shade(mu.HPDI, weight.seq)

## (c) What aspects of the model fit concern you? Describe the kinds of assumptions
## you would change, if any, to improve the model. You don’t have to write any new code. 
## Just explain what the model appears to be doing a bad job of, and what you hypothesize 
## would be a better model.

# The MAP line of the linear regression does not follow the central path of the data.
# Hence, the model does not fit the data well. A cubic regression might be a better 
# model, considering the curvature of the distribution. 

```

<br>

<span style="color:purple">***Check model fit with cubic regression***</span>

```{r test.cubic}

## Test cubic regression
# Standardize the weights
weight.s <- (d2$weight - mean(d2$weight))/ sd(d2$weight)

# Pre-calculate weight.s2 and weight.s3
weight.s2 <- weight.s^2
weight.s3 <- weight.s^3

# Fit the map model
mN <- rethinking::map(
  alist( 
     height ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
        mu <- a + b1*weight.s + b2*weight.s2 + b3*weight.s3,
        a ~ dnorm(120, 20),
        b1 ~ dnorm(6, 10),
        b2 ~ dnorm(0, 10),
        b3 ~ dnorm(0, 10),
        sigma ~ dunif(0, 64)
  ), 
  
  data = d2
)

precis(mN)

# Define weight sequence
weight.seq <- seq(from = -2, to = 3, length.out = 61)

# Create a list of predictor data
pred_dat <- list(weight.s = weight.seq, weight.s2 = weight.seq^2, weight.s3 = weight.seq^3)

# Calculate predicted mu values for based on model and predictor values
mu <- link(mN, data = pred_dat)

# Calculate mean of predicted mu values across column
mu.mean <- apply(mu, 2, mean)

# Calculate PI of predicted mu values (89% interval)
mu.PI <- apply(mu, 2, PI, prob = 0.89)

# Simulate height values based on model and predictor values
sim.height <- sim(mN, data = pred_dat)

# Calculate PI of simulated heights
height.PI <- apply(sim.height, 2, PI, prob = 0.89)

# Plot raw data
plot(height ~ weight.s, d2, col = col.alpha("red", 0.5), xlab = "weight")

# Add map line
lines(weight.seq, mu.mean)

# Shade PI for mu values
shade(mu.PI, weight.seq)

# Shade PI of simulated heights
shade(height.PI, weight.seq)

## Convert back to natural scale
# Remove x-axis 
plot(height ~ weight.s, d2, col = col.alpha("red", 0.5), xaxt = "n", xlab = "weight")

# Defines location of the labels, in standardized units
at <- c(-1, 0, 1, 2, 3)

# Convert those units back to the original scale
labels <- at*sd(d2$weight) + mean(d2$weight)

# Draw the axis                    
axis(side = 1 , at = at , labels = round(labels,0))

# Draw map line
lines(weight.seq, mu.mean)

# Shade PI for mu values
shade(mu.PI, weight.seq)

# Shade PI of simulated heights
shade(height.PI, weight.seq)


```

<br>

<span style="color:purple">***Given answer:***</span>

```{r 3.7}
set.seed(37)
## (a)First make a new data frame with just the non-adults in it:
data(Howell1)
d <- Howell1
d3 <- d[ d$age < 18 , ]
str(d3)

# Now find the quadratic approximate posterior. The code is the same as before. 
# The data frame just changes.
m <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        height ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + b*weight ,
        a ~ dnorm( 100 , 100 ),
        b ~ dnorm( 0 , 10 ) ,
sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 50 ) ),
    data=d3 )
precis(m)
# The estimates suggest that the MAP coefficient for weight is 2.7. This implies that 
# for a unit change of 1kg of weight, we predict an average of 2.7cm of increase in height.

## (b) Now to plot the raw data and superimpose the model estimates, modify the code in 
## Chapter 4. We will sample from the naive posterior, then compute 90% intervals for the 
## mean and predicted heights. This is what the complete code looks like, if you opt not 
## to use the convenience functions link and sim:
post <- extract.samples( m )
w.seq <- seq(from=1,to=45,length.out=50)
mu <- sapply( w.seq , function(z) mean( post$a + post$b*z ) )
mu.ci <- sapply( w.seq , function(z)
    HPDI( post$a + post$b*z , prob=0.9 ) )
pred.ci <- sapply( w.seq , function(z)
    HPDI( rnorm(10000,post$a + post$b*z,post$sigma) , 0.9 ) )

# And then to plot everything:
plot( height ~ weight , data=d3 ,
    col=col.alpha("slateblue",0.5) , cex=0.5 )
lines( w.seq , mu )
lines( w.seq , mu.ci[1,] , lty=2 )
lines( w.seq , mu.ci[2,] , lty=2 )
lines( w.seq , pred.ci[1,] , lty=2 )
lines( w.seq , pred.ci[2,] , lty=2 )

## (c) The major problem with this model appears to be that the relationship between 
## weight and height, for non-adults, isn’t very linear. Instead it is curved. As a result, 
## at low weight values, the predicted mean is above most of the actual heights. At middle 
## weight values, the predicted mean is below most of the heights. Then again at high 
## weight values, the mean is above the heights.
# A parabolic model would likely fit these data much better. But that’s not the only option. 
# What we’re after essentially is some way to model a reduction of the slope between height 
# and weight, as weight increases. And onwards to the next solution, which does that, for the 
# entire data.

```

<br>

> 4H3. Suppose a colleague of yours, who works on allometry, glances at the practice problems just above. Your colleague exclaims, “That’s silly. Everyone knows that it’s only the logarithm of body weight that scales with height!” Let’s take your colleague’s advice and see what happens.

> (a) Model the relationship between height (cm) and the natural logarithm of weight (log-kg). Use the entire Howell1 data frame, all 544 rows, adults and non-adults. Fit this model, using quadratic approximation:

```{r 4H3a}

# Use entire Howell1 data frame
data("Howell1")
d <- Howell1
str(d)

qfit <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    height ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + b * log(weight),
    a ~ dnorm(178, 100),
    b ~ dnorm(0, 100),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 50)
  ), 
  
  data = d
)

precis(qfit)
# When predictor value is zero, the height is -23.78, meaning there is no height at zero weight.
# When log value of weight increases by 1 unit, height will increase by 47 cm. 


```

<br>

> (b) Use samples from the quadratic approximate posterior of the model in (a) to superimpose on the plot: (1) the predicted mean height as a function of weight, (2) the 97% HPDI for the mean, and (3) the 97% HPDI for predicted heights.

```{r 4H3b}

# Define weight sequence
weight.seq <- seq(from = 3, to = 80, by = 1)

# Calculate mu values for each data and sample from posterior distribution using link
mu <- link(qfit, data = data.frame(weight = weight.seq))
str(mu)

# Compute mean and HPDI of mu 
mu.mean <- apply(mu, 2, mean)
mu.HPDI <- apply(mu, 2, HPDI, prob = 0.97)

# Start with the given plot
plot( height ~ weight , data=Howell1 ,
    col=col.alpha(rangi2,0.4) )

# plot the MAP line, aka the mean mu for each weight
lines( weight.seq , mu.mean )

# plot a shaded region for 97% HPDI
shade( mu.HPDI , weight.seq )

# Pre-define data
pre_data <- list (weight = weight.seq)

# Simulate height values based on model and predictor values
sim.height <- sim(qfit, data = pre_data )

# Calculate PI of simulated heights
height.PI <- apply(sim.height, 2, PI, prob = 0.97)

# Shade predicted height HPDI
shade(height.PI, weight.seq)

```

<br>

<span style="color:purple">***Given answer:***</span>

```{r 3.11}

## (a) You can just use log inside the call to map:
data(Howell1)
d <- Howell1
mlw <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        height ~ dnorm( mean=mu , sd=sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + b*log(weight) ,
        a ~ dnorm( 138 , 100 ) ,
        b ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 50 )
),
    data=d )
precis(mlw)

# Pretty hard to know what to make of these estimates, aside from the fact that the 
# confidence intervals are quite narrow, owing to there being 544 rows. The estimate 
# for b (β) is hard to understand, because it refers to log-kg, not raw kg. It means 
# that for every increase of 1 log-kg of weight, you expect a increase of 47 cm of height. 
# But what’s a log-kg? You want to know what the model predicts on the natural scale 
# of measurement. So now to plotting...

## (b) Begin by sampling from the naive posterior and computing the confidence intervals 
## as per the examples in the book. Again, I’ll not use the convenience functions, 
## but it’s fine if you did.
post <- extract.samples(mlw)
lw.seq <- seq(from=1.4,to=4.2,length.out=50)
mu <- sapply( lw.seq , function(z) mean( post$a+post$b*z ) )
mu.ci <- sapply( lw.seq , function(z) HPDI( post$a+post$b*z ) )
h.ci <- sapply( lw.seq , function(z)
    HPDI( rnorm(10000,post$a+post$b*z,post$sigma) ) )

# Now you have lists of numbers that can be plotted to produce the confidence curves. 
# But how to translate back to the non-log scale of measurement on the horizontal axis? 
# Just exponentiate the x-axis coordinates in lw.seq, and the job is done:
plot( height ~ weight , data=d , col=col.alpha("slateblue",0.4) )
lines( exp(lw.seq) , mu )
lines( exp(lw.seq) , mu.ci[1,] , lty=2 )
lines( exp(lw.seq) , mu.ci[2,] , lty=2 )
lines( exp(lw.seq) , h.ci[1,] , lty=2 )
lines( exp(lw.seq) , h.ci[2,] , lty=2 )

# The model may have been linear, but plotted on the raw scale of measurement, it is 
# clearly non-linear. Not only is the trend for the mean curved, but the variance around 
# the mean is not constant, on this scale. Instead, the variance around the mean increases 
# with weight. On the scale you fit the model on, the variance was assumed to be constant. 
# But once you transform the measurement scale, it usually won’t be.

# Notice also that the estimate for the mean is so precise that you can hardly even see 
# the confidence interval for it. Don’t get too confident about such results, though. 
# Remember, all inferences of the model are conditional on the model. Even estimated 
# trends that do a terrible job of prediction can have tight confidence intervals, 
# when the data set is large.

```

<br>

# Chapter 5: Multivariate Linear Models

<br>

Multivariate regression uses more than one predictor variable to model an outcome. Reasons often given for multivariate models include:

- Statistical “control” for confounds
    - A confound is a variable that may be correlated with another variable of interest. In a particularly important type of confound, known as Simpson’s paradox, the entire direction of an apparent association between a predictor and outcome can be reversed by considering a confound

- Multiple causation
    - Even when confounds are absent, due for example to tight experimental control, a phenomenon may really arise from multiple causes. Furthermore, when causation is multiple, one cause can hide another. Multivariate models can help in such settings.

- Interaction
    - Even when variables are completely uncorrelated, the importance of each may still depend upon the other. Such interactions occur in a very large number of systems. So effective inference about one variable will usually depend upon consideration of other variables.
    
<br>

## Spurious association

Linear regression model for correlation between age at marriage and divorce rate:


<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}D_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma) \\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_A A_i \\\alpha &\sim Normal(10, 10) \\\beta_A &\sim Normal(0, 1) \\\sigma &\sim Uniform(0, 10)\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

```
Di = the divorce rate for State i

Ai = State i’s median age at marriage

```

```{r 5.1}

par(mfrow = c(2, 2), mar = c(4, 4, 4, 4))

# load data
data(WaffleDivorce)
d <- WaffleDivorce

## Median age at marriage vs. divorce rate
# standardize predictor
d$MedianAgeMarriage.s <- (d$MedianAgeMarriage-mean(d$MedianAgeMarriage))/
    sd(d$MedianAgeMarriage)

# fit model
m5.1 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        Divorce ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bA * MedianAgeMarriage.s ,
        a ~ dnorm( 10 , 10 ) ,
        bA ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 )
) , data = d )

# Check precis output
precis(m5.1)
# each additional standard deviation of delay in marriage (1.24 years- the difference between
# two data points after converting back to natural scale) predicts a decrease of 
# about one divorce per thousand adults, with a 89% interval from about −1.4 to −0.7.
# So it’s reliably negative, even though the magnitude of the difference may vary quite a lot—
# the upper bound is half the lower bound. Of course there’s nothing special about the interval
# boundaries, but the magnitude of the difference means that even though the association here 
# (conditional on model and data) is implausibly positive, it could be both much stronger 
# or weaker than the mean.

# compute percentile interval of mean
MAM.seq <- seq( from=-3 , to=3.5 , length.out=30 )
mu <- link( m5.1 , data=data.frame(MedianAgeMarriage.s=MAM.seq) )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )

# plot it all
plot( Divorce ~ MedianAgeMarriage.s , data=d , col=rangi2 , main = "Standardized scale")
abline( m5.1 )
shade( mu.PI , MAM.seq )

# Convert to natural scale
plot( Divorce ~ MedianAgeMarriage.s , data=d , col=rangi2, xaxt = "n",
      xlab ="MedianAgeMarriage", main = "Natural scale")
at <- c(-3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4)
labels <- at*sd(d$MedianAgeMarriage) + mean(d$MedianAgeMarriage)
axis(side = 1 , at = at , labels = round(labels,2))
abline( m5.1 )
shade( mu.PI , MAM.seq )

## Marriage rate vs. divorce rate
# standardize predictor (marriage rate)
d$Marriage.s <- (d$Marriage - mean(d$Marriage))/sd(d$Marriage)

# fit model
m5.2 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        Divorce ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bR * Marriage.s ,
        a ~ dnorm( 10 , 10 ) ,
        bR ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
    sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 )
) , data = d )

# check precis output
precis(m5.2)
# This shows an increase of 0.6 divorces for every additional standard deviation 
# of marriage rate (3.8). this relationship isn’t as strong as the previous one.

# compute percentile interval of mean
MAM.seq <- seq( from=-3 , to=3 , length.out=30 )
mu <- link( m5.2 , data=data.frame(Marriage.s=MAM.seq) )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )

# plot it all
plot( Divorce ~ Marriage.s , data=d , col=rangi2 )
abline( m5.2 )
shade( mu.PI , MAM.seq )

# Convert to natural scale
plot( Divorce ~ Marriage.s , data=d , col=rangi2, xaxt = "n",
      xlab ="Marriage")
at <- c(-3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3)
labels <- at*sd(d$Marriage) + mean(d$Marriage)
axis(side = 1 , at = at , labels = round(labels,2))
abline( m5.2 )
shade( mu.PI , MAM.seq )

```

<br>

Merely comparing parameter means between different bivariate regressions is no way to decide which predictor is better. Both of these predictors could provide independent value, or they could be redundant, or one could eliminate the value of the other. So we’ll build a multivariate model with the goal of measuring the partial value of each predictor. The question we want answered is:

  ***What is the predictive value of a variable, once I already know all of the other predictor variables?***

So for example once you fit a multivariate regression to predict divorce using both marriage rate and age at marriage, the model answers the questions:

  (1) After I already know marriage rate, what additional value is there in also knowing age at marriage?

  (2) After I already know age at marriage, what additional value is there in also knowing marriage rate?
  
The parameter estimates corresponding to each predictor are the (often opaque) answers to these questions.

<br>

### Multivariate notation

Multivariate regression formulas look a lot like the polynomial models- they add more parameters and variables to the definition of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu_i}" title="" />. The strategy is straightforward:

(1) Nominate the predictor variables you want in the linear model of the mean.

(2) For each predictor, make a parameter that will measure its association with the outcome.

(3) Multiply the parameter by the variable and add that term to the linear model.

Example model that predicts divorce rate, using both marriage rate and age at marriage:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}D_i &\sim Normal(\mu, \sigma)\ &&&  [likelihood]\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_R R_i + \beta_A A_i\ &&&  [linear~model]\\\alpha &\sim Normal(10, 10)\ &&& [prior~for~\alpha]\\\beta_R &\sim Normal(0, 1)\ &&&  [prior~for~\beta_R]\\\beta_A &\sim Normal(0, 1)\ &&&   [prior~for~\beta_A]\\\sigma &\sim Uniform(0, 10)\ &&&  [prior~for~\sigma]\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

```
R = marriage rate 

A = age at marriage

```
<br>

<span style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Compact notation and the design matrix**</span></span>

Linear model with n number of predictor variables:

![](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\boldsymbol{\mu_i = \alpha + \beta_1 x_{1i} + \beta_2 x_{2i} + ... + \beta_n x_{ni}})

<br>

In compact form:

![](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\boldsymbol{\mu_i = \alpha + \sum_{j = 1}^{n} \beta_j x_{ji}})


```

j = an index over predictor variables 

n = the number of predictor variables

```
<br>

Both of these forms may be read as *the mean is a modeled as the sum of an intercept and an additive combination of the products of parameters and predictors.* Even more compactly, using matrix notation:

![](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\boldsymbol{m = Xb})

```

m = a vector of predicted means, one for each row in the data

b = a (column) vector of parameters, one for each predictor variable

X = a matrix

This matrix is called a design matrix. It has as many rows as the data, and as many columns as
there are predictors plus one. So X is basically a data frame, but with an extra first column. 
The extra column is filled with 1s. These 1s are multiplied by the first parameter, which is 
the intercept, and so return the unmodified intercept. When X is matrix-multiplied by b, you get 
the predicted means. In R notation, this operation is X %*% b.

```
<br>

### Fitting the model

To fit this model to the divorce data, we just expand the linear model.

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}D_i &\sim Normal(\mu, \sigma)\ &&&  Divorce &\sim dnorm(mu, sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_R R_i + \beta_A A_i\ &&&  mu &\leftarrow a + bR^*Marriage.s + bA^*MedianAgeMarriage.s\\\alpha &\sim Normal(10, 10)\ &&&  a &\sim dnorm(10, 10)\\ \beta_R &\sim Normal(0, 1)\ &&& bR &\sim dnorm(0, 1)\\\beta_A &\sim Normal(0, 1)\ &&& bA &\sim dnorm(0, 1)\\\sigma &\sim Uniform(0, 10)\ &&& sigma &\sim dunif(0, 10)\\\end{align*}" title="" />


```{r 5.4}

m5.3 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        Divorce ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bR*Marriage.s + bA*MedianAgeMarriage.s ,
        a ~ dnorm( 10 , 10 ) ,
        bR ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
        bA ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 )
),
    data = d )

precis( m5.3 )
# The posterior mean for marriage rate, bR, is now close to zero, with plenty of probability 
# of both sides of zero. The posterior mean for age at marriage, bA, has actually gotten slightly 
# farther from zero, but is essentially unchanged.

# Visualize the posterior distribution estimates
plot(precis(m5.3)) # same as plot(m5.3)
# The result, with MAP values shown by the points and the percentile intervals 
# by the solid horizontal lines. 
# You can interpret these estimates as saying: Once we know median age at marriage for a State, 
# there is little or no additional predictive power in also knowing the rate of marriage in that State.

```

<br>

### Plotting multivariate posteriors

Three types of interpretive plots:

(1) ***Predictor residual plots.*** These plots show the outcome against residual predictor values.

(2) ***Counterfactual plots.*** These show the implied predictions for imaginary experiments in which the different predictor variables can be changed independently of one another.

(3) ***Posterior prediction plots.*** These show model-based predictions against raw data, or otherwise display the error in prediction.

<br>

#### Predictor residual plots

A predictor variable residual is the average prediction error when we use all of the other predictor variables to model a predictor of interest. The benefit of computing these things is that, once plotted against the outcome, we have a bivariate regression of sorts that has already “controlled” for all of the other predictor variables. It just leaves in the variation that is not expected by the model of the mean, <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu}" title="" />, as a function of the other predictors.

In our multivariate model of divorce rate, we have two predictors: 

(1) marriage rate (Marriage.s) 

(2) median age at marriage (MedianAgeMarriage.s) 

To compute predictor residuals for either, we just use the other predictor to model it. The model for marraige rate:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}R_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta A_i\\\alpha &\sim Normal(0, 10)\\\beta &\sim Normal(0, 1)\\\sigma &\sim Uniform(0, 10)\\\end{align*}" title="" />


```{r 5.4a}

# Fit the model using standardized variables
m5.4 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        Marriage.s ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + b*MedianAgeMarriage.s ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0 , 10 ) ,
        b ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 ) ),
data = d )

## Compute the residuals by subtracting the observed marriage rate in each State from 
## the predicted rate, based upon median age at marriage
# compute expected value at MAP, for each State
mu <- coef(m5.4)['a'] + coef(m5.4)['b']*d$MedianAgeMarriage.s

# compute residual for each State
m.resid <- d$Marriage.s - mu
m.resid
# States with positive residuals marry fast for their age of marriage, 
# while States with negative residuals marry slow for their age of marriage. 

# plot the relationship between these two variables, and show the residuals
plot( Marriage.s ~ MedianAgeMarriage.s , d , col=rangi2 )
abline( m5.4 )

# loop over States
for ( i in 1:length(m.resid) ) {
    x <- d$MedianAgeMarriage.s[i] # x location of line segment
    y <- d$Marriage.s[i] # observed endpoint of line segment
    # draw the line segment
    lines( c(x,x) , c(mu[i],y) , lwd=0.5 , col=col.alpha("black",0.7) )
}
# Residual marriage rate in each State, after accounting for the linear association 
# with median age at marriage. Each gray line segment is a residual, the distance of 
# each observed marriage rate from the expected value, attempting to predict marriage 
# rate with median age at marriage alone. So States that lie above the black regression 
# line have higher rates of marriage than expected, according to age at marriage. 
# Those below the line have lower rates than expected.
# Notice that the residuals are variation in marriage rate that is left over, 
# after taking out the purely linear relationship between the two variables.
```
<br>

<span style="color:purple">***Residual plots for the divorce rate***</span>

```{r divorce}

## Compute the predicted divorce rate value at MAP based on marriage rate
# Fit the model using standardized variables

m5.41 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        Divorce ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + b*Marriage.s ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0 , 10 ) ,
        b ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 ) ),
data = d )

m5.41

# compute expected value at MAP, for each State
mu <- coef(m5.41)['a'] + coef(m5.41)['b']*d$Marriage.s

# compute residual for each State
d.resid <- d$Divorce - mu
d.resid

# plot the relationship between these two variables, and show the residuals
plot( Divorce ~ Marriage.s , d , col="brown" , pch = 16)
abline( m5.41, col = "brown")

# loop over States
for ( i in 1:length(d.resid) ) {
    x <- d$Marriage.s[i] # x location of line segment
    y <- d$Divorce[i] # observed endpoint of line segment
    # draw the line segment
    lines( c(x,x) , c(mu[i],y) , lwd=0.5 , col=col.alpha("brown",0.7) )
}

# To add PI shade
# compute percentile interval of mean
MAM.seq <- seq( from=-2 , to=3 , length.out=30 )
mu <- link( m5.41 , data=data.frame(Marriage.s=MAM.seq) )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )
shade(mu.PI, MAM.seq, col = col.alpha("brown", alpha = 0.2))

```

<br>

```{r divorce1}

## Compute the predicted divorce rate value at MAP based on median age of marriage
# Fit the model using standardized variables

m5.42 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        Divorce ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + b*MedianAgeMarriage.s ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0 , 10 ) ,
        b ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 ) ),
data = d )

m5.42

# compute expected value at MAP, for each State
mu <- coef(m5.42)['a'] + coef(m5.42)['b']*d$MedianAgeMarriage.s

# compute residual for each State
d.resid <- d$Divorce - mu
d.resid
# States with positive residuals marry fast for their age of marriage, 
# while States with negative residuals marry slow for their age of marriage. 

# plot the relationship between these two variables, and show the residuals
plot( Divorce ~ MedianAgeMarriage.s , d , col="brown" , pch = 16)
abline( m5.42, col = "brown")

# loop over States
for ( i in 1:length(d.resid) ) {
    x <- d$MedianAgeMarriage.s[i] # x location of line segment
    y <- d$Divorce[i] # observed endpoint of line segment
    # draw the line segment
    lines( c(x,x) , c(mu[i],y) , lwd=0.5 , col=col.alpha("brown",0.7) )
}

# To add PI shade
# compute percentile interval of mean
MAM.seq <- seq( from=-3 , to=4 , length.out=30 )
mu <- link( m5.42 , data=data.frame(MedianAgeMarriage.s=MAM.seq) )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )
shade(mu.PI, MAM.seq, col = col.alpha("brown", alpha = 0.2))

```

<br>

<span style="color:purple">***Predictor residual plots for the divorce data***</span>

```{r divorce2}

par(mfrow = c(1,2))

## Divorce rate vs. marriage rate residuals
# Fit a map model for divorce rate based on marriage rate residuals
m5.43 <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    Divorce ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + b*m.resid,
    a ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    b ~ dnorm(0, 1),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
  ), 
  data = d
)

m5.43

# Plot the data
plot(Divorce ~ m.resid, d, col = rangi2, ylim = c(6, 16),
     xlab = "Marriage rate residuals", ylab = "Divorce rate")
abline(m5.43)
abline(v = 0, lty = 2)
text(0.05, 15, "faster", pos = 4)  
text(-0.05, 15, "slower", pos = 2)

# Shade PI 
mar.seq <- seq(from = -2, to = 2, length.out = 30)
mu <- link(m5.43, data = data.frame(m.resid = mar.seq))
mu.PI <- apply(mu, 2, PI)
shade(mu.PI, mar.seq)

## Divorce rate Vs. Age of marriage residuals
# Fit the model using standardized variables
m5.44 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        MedianAgeMarriage.s ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + b*Marriage.s ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0 , 10 ) ,
        b ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 ) ),
data = d )

m5.44

# compute expected value at MAP, for each State
mu <- coef(m5.44)['a'] + coef(m5.44)['b']*d$Marriage.s

# compute residual for each State

ma.resid <- d$MedianAgeMarriage.s - mu
ma.resid

# Calculate residual for median age of marriage
# Fit a map model of divorce rate based on median age of marriage
m5.45 <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    Divorce ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + b*ma.resid,
    a ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    b ~ dnorm(0, 1),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
  ),
  data = d
)

m5.45

# Plot the data
plot(Divorce ~ ma.resid, d, col = rangi2, ylim = c(6, 16),
     xlab = "Age of marriage residuals", ylab = "Divorce rate")
abline(m5.45)
abline(v = 0, lty = 2)
text(0.05, 15, "older", pos = 4)  
text(-0.05, 15, "younger", pos = 2)

# Shade PI 
mar.seq <- seq(from = -3, to = 3, length.out = 30)
mu <- link(m5.45, data = data.frame(ma.resid = mar.seq))
mu.PI <- apply(mu, 2, PI)
shade(mu.PI, mar.seq)
# Left: States with fast marriage rates for their median age of marriage have about 
# the same divorce rates as do States with slow marriage rates. This plot displays the 
# linear relationship between divorce and marriage rates, having statistically 
# “controlled” for median age of marriage. The vertical dashed line indicates marriage 
# rate that exactly matches the expectation from median age at marriage. The slope of 
# the regression line is −0.13, exactly what we found in the multivariate model, m5.3.
## I got -0.17 for residual plot here.

# Right: States with old median age of marriage for their marriage rate have lower 
# divorce rates, while States with young median age of marriage have higher divorce rates.
# This plot displays linear relationship between divorce and median age at marriage, 
# “controlling” for marriage rate. The slope of the regression line 
# here is −1.13, again the same as in the multivariate model, m5.3.

# There’s direct value in seeing the model-based predictions displayed against the outcome, 
# after subtracting out the influence of other predictors.

```

<br>

#### Counterfactual plots

A second sort of inferential plot displays the implied predictions of the model. The counterfactual plots can be produced for any values of the predictor variables you like, even unobserved or impossible combinations. 

The simplest use of a counterfactual plot is to see how the predictions change as you change only one predictor at a time. This means holding the values of all predictors constant, except for a single predictor of interest. Such predictions will not necessarily look like your raw data— they are counterfactual after all— but they will help you understand the implications of the model.

<br>

</span style="color:purple">***Counterfactual plots for the multivariate divorce model, m5.3***<span>

```{r 5.9}

par(mfrow = c(1,2))

## Begin with a plot showing the impact of changes in Marriage.s on predictions

# prepare new counterfactual data
A.avg <- mean( d$MedianAgeMarriage.s ) 
R.seq <- seq( from=-3 , to=3 , length.out=30 )
pred.data <- data.frame(
    Marriage.s=R.seq,
    MedianAgeMarriage.s=A.avg
) # Marriage.s changes across the values in MR.seq, while the other predictor is held 
  # constant at its mean, MAM.avg

# compute counterfactual mean divorce (mu)
mu <- link( m5.3 , data=pred.data ) #m5.3: divorce based on marriage.s & MedianAgemarriage.s
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )

# simulate counterfactual divorce outcomes
R.sim <- sim( m5.3 , data=pred.data , n=1e4 )

R.PI <- apply( R.sim , 2 , PI )

# display predictions, hiding raw data with type="n"
plot( Divorce ~ Marriage.s , data=d , type="n" )
mtext( "MedianAgeMarriage.s = 0" )
lines( R.seq , mu.mean )
shade( mu.PI , R.seq )
shade( R.PI , R.seq )

## Now with Marriage.s set to its average and MedianAgeMarriage.s allowed to vary

# Prepare new counterfactual data
R.avg <- mean( d$Marriage.s )
A.seq <- seq( from=-3 , to=3.5 , length.out=30 )
pred.data2 <- data.frame(
    Marriage.s=R.avg,
    MedianAgeMarriage.s=A.seq
)

# Calculate counterfactual mean divorce (mu)
mu <- link( m5.3 , data=pred.data2 )
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )

# simulate counterfactual divorce outcomes
A.sim <- sim( m5.3 , data=pred.data2 , n=1e4 )

A.PI <- apply( A.sim , 2 , PI )

# display predictions, hiding raw data with type="n"
plot( Divorce ~ MedianAgeMarriage.s , data=d , type="n" )
mtext( "Marriage.s = 0" )
lines( A.seq , mu.mean )
shade( mu.PI , A.seq )
shade( A.PI , A.seq )

# Each plot shows the change in predicted mean across values of a single predictor, 
# holding the other predictor constant at its mean value (zero in both cases). 
# Shaded regions show 89% percentile intervals of the mean (dark, narrow) and 
# 89% prediction intervals (light, wide).

```

<br>

In this example, the difficulty of separately manipulating marriage rate and marriage age doesn’t impede inference much, only because marriage rate has almost no effect on prediction, once median age of marriage is taken into account. But in many problems, more than one predictor variable has a sizable impact on the outcome. In that case, while these counterfactual plots always help in understanding the model, they may also mislead by displaying predictions for impossible combinations of predictor values. If our goal is to intervene in the world, there may not be any realistic way to manipulate each predictor without also manipulating the others. 

<br>

#### Posterior prediction plots

Checking the model fit against the observed data is useful in many ways. Two uses among them are:

(1) Did the model fit correctly?
    - Many common software and user errors can be more easily diagnosed by comparing implied predictions to the raw data. Some caution is required, because not all models try to exactly match the sample.
    
(2) How does the model fail?
    - Sometimes, the model fits correctly but is still so poor for our purposes that it must be discarded. More often, a model predicts well in some respects, but not in others. By inspecting the individual cases where the model makes poor predictions, you might get an idea of how to improve the model.
    
<br>

<span style="color:purple">***Posterior predictive plots for the multivariate divorce model, m5.3***</span>

```{r 5.11}

## begin by simulating predictions, averaging over the posterior

# call link without specifying new data
# so it uses original data
mu <- link( m5.3 )

# summarize samples across cases
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )

# simulate observations
# again no new data, so uses original data
divorce.sim <- sim( m5.3 , n=1e4 )
divorce.PI <- apply( divorce.sim , 2 , PI )

# plot predictions against observed
plot( mu.mean ~ d$Divorce , col=rangi2 , ylim=range(mu.PI) ,
    xlab="Observed divorce" , ylab="Predicted divorce")

#  add a line to show perfect prediction and 
# line segments for the confidence interval of each prediction
abline( a=0 , b=1 , lty=2 )
for ( i in 1:nrow(d) )
    lines( rep(d$Divorce[i],2) , c(mu.PI[1,i],mu.PI[2,i]) ,
        col=rangi2 )

# label a few select points using 'identify' (only work in R Script)
# identify( x=d$Divorce , y=mu.mean , labels=d$Loc , cex=0.8 )
# rmarkdown doesn't allow to select data points 

# Define the indices of the points to label
indices <- c(13, 44)  

# Add text labels to specific points
text(x = d$Divorce[indices], y = mu.mean[indices], labels = d$Loc[indices], cex = 0.8, pos = 2)
# Predicted divorce rate against observed, with 89% confidence in- tervals of the average prediction. 
# The dashed line shows perfect prediction. The model under-predicts for States with very high divorce 
# rates while it over-predicts for States with very low divorce rates- e.g., Idaho (ID) and Utah (UT), 
# both of which have much lower divorce rates than the model expects them to have.
```

<br>

The plot above makes it hard to see the amount of prediction error, in many cases. For this reason, lots of people also use residual plots that show the mean prediction error for each row. 


```{r 5.14, fig.height=8}
# compute residuals
divorce.resid <- d$Divorce - mu.mean

# get ordering by divorce rate
o <- order(divorce.resid)

# make the plot
dotchart( divorce.resid[o] , labels=d$Loc[o] , xlim=c(-6,5) , cex=0.7)
abline( v=0 , col=col.alpha("black",0.2) )
for ( i in 1:nrow(d) ) {
    j <- o[i] # which State in order
    lines( d$Divorce[j]-c(mu.PI[1,j],mu.PI[2,j]) , rep(i,2) )
    points( d$Divorce[j]-c(divorce.PI[1,j],divorce.PI[2,j]) , rep(i,2),
            pch=3 , cex=0.6 , col="gray" )
}

# Average prediction error for each State, with 89% interval of the mean (black line) 
# and 89% prediction interval (gray +). 

```

<br>

Yet another common use for these simulations is to construct novel predictor residual plots. Once you’ve computed the divorce residuals, as you did just above, you can plot those residuals against new predictor variables. This is a quick way to see if remaining variation in the outcome is associated with another predictor.

```{r 5.14a}

# Calculate waffle houses per capita
d$Wafflehouse_per_capita <- d$WaffleHouses/d$Population

# Fit the map model 
m5.6c <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    divorce.resid ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + b*d$Wafflehouse_per_capita,
    a ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    b ~ dnorm(0, 1),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
  ), 
  data = d
)

m5.6c

# Plot divorce residue against waffle house per capita
plot(divorce.resid ~ Wafflehouse_per_capita, data = d, col = rangi2,
     xlab = "Waffles per capita", ylab = "Divorce error", ylim = c(-5, 4))

# Add the regression line
abline(coef(m5.6c)[1], coef(m5.6c)[2])

# Define the indices of the points to label
indices <- c(20, 4, 1, 25, 11, 40, 13)  

# Add text labels to specific points
text(x = d$Wafflehouse_per_capita[indices], y = divorce.resid[indices], 
     labels = d$Loc[indices], cex = 0.8, pos = 3)
# I couldn't use PI function to get the CI of the abline. I think it is because the calculation
# of PI  considers divorce.resid as samples and treat them as such, while in reality, they are
# prediction error of each sample. 

## So, I will use lm function and ggplot to recreate the plot in textbook
ggplot(d, aes(x = Wafflehouse_per_capita, y = divorce.resid)) +
  geom_point(color = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.8), size = 2) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", fullrange = T,
              color  = "black", size = 1/2, 
              fill   = "gray", alpha = 1/3) +
 
  geom_text(aes(label=ifelse(divorce.resid > 2.33022867,as.character(Loc),'')), 
            hjust = 0, vjust = -0.5) +
  
  geom_text(aes(label = ifelse(divorce.resid > 1.73858361 & divorce.resid <= 1.8, 
                               as.character(Loc), "")), hjust = 1, vjust = 1.2) +
  
  geom_text(aes(label = ifelse(divorce.resid > 1 & divorce.resid <= 1.15377608, 
                               as.character(Loc), "")), hjust = 1, vjust = -0.5) +
  
  geom_text(aes(label = ifelse(divorce.resid > -1.34199783 & divorce.resid <= -1.3, 
                               as.character(Loc), "")), hjust = 1, vjust = -0.5) +
  
  geom_text(aes(label = ifelse(divorce.resid > 1.15 & divorce.resid <= 1.16, 
                               as.character(Loc), "")), hjust = 1, vjust = -0.5) +
  
  geom_text(aes(label=ifelse(divorce.resid < -4.38753672,as.character(Loc),'')), 
            hjust = 0, vjust = -0.5) +
  
  labs(x = "Waffles per capita", y = "Divorce error") +
  theme_minimal() 
# Average prediction error (residuals) against number of Waffle Houses per capita, with 
# superimposed regression of the two variables.
# A small positive correlation remains between divorce rate and Waffle House, despite already 
# “controlling” for marriage rate and median age at marriage in each State. This does not mean 
# that the correlation is real. No matter how many predictors you’ve already included in a 
# regression, it’s still possible to find spurious correlations with the remaining variation.

```

<br>

<span style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Simulating spurious association**</span>

One way that spurious associations between a predictor and outcome can arise is when a truly causal predictor, call it x~real~, influences both the outcome, y, and a spurious predictor, x~spur~.


```{r paired_plot}

N <- 100                                          # number of cases                       

x_real <- rnorm(N)                                # x_real as Gaussian with mean 0 and stddev 1

x_spur <- rnorm(N, x_real)                        # x_spur as Gaussian with mean = x_real

y <- rnorm(N, x_real)                             # y as Gaussian with mean = x_real

d <- data.frame(y, x_real, x_spur)                # bind all together in data frame

pairs(d)

# The data frame d has 100 simulated cases. Because x_real influences both y and x_spur, 
# you can think of x_spur as another outcome of x_real, but one which we mistake as a 
# potential predictor of y. As a result, both x_real and x_spur are correlated with y. 
# You can see this in the scatterplots from pairs(d). But when you include both x variables 
# in a linear regression predicting y, the posterior mean for the association between y and
# x_spur will be close to zero, while the comparable mean for xreal will be closer to 1.

```

<br>

## Masked relationship

A second reason to use more than one predictor variable is to measure the direct influences of multiple factors on an outcome, when none of those influences is apparent from bivariate relationships. This kind of problem tends to arise when there are two predictor variables that are correlated with one another. However, one of these is positively correlated with the outcome and the other is negatively correlated with it.

```{r 5.16}

# Load data on composition of milk across primate species
data(milk)
d <- milk
str(d) #  29 rows (cases) for 8 variables (columns)

## First, simple bivariate regression between kilocalories and neocortex percent
# Check the neocortex column to see any missing (NA) values
d$neocortex.perc
# If you pass a vector like this to a likelihood function like dnorm, it doesn’t know what to do.
# After all, what’s the probability of a missing value? Whatever the answer, it isn’t a number, 
# and so dnorm returns a NaN. 

# Manually drop all the cases with missing values
dcc <- d[complete.cases(d), ] # gives new data frame with 17 rows

m5.5 <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    kcal.per.g ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + bn*neocortex.perc,
    a ~ dnorm(0, 100),
    bn ~ dnorm(0, 1),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 1)
  ),
  data = dcc
)

# Check precis and add digits=3 to the precis call. The reason is that the posterior mean for 
# bn is very small. Need more digits to see that it’s not exactly zero—a change from the smallest
# neocortex percent in the data, 55%, to the largest, 76%, would result in an expected change of
# only: less than 0.1 kilocalories (0.09008296 kcal)
precis(m5.5, digits = 3)
coef(m5.5)["bn"] * (75 - 55)

```

<br>

The kilocalories in the data range from less than 0.5 to more than 0.9 per gram, so this association isn’t so impressive. More importantly, it isn’t very precise. The 89% interval of the parameter extends a good distance on both sides of zero.

```{r 5.23}

## Plot the predicted mean and 89% interval for the mean to see this more easily

np.seq <- 0:100
pred.data <- data.frame( neocortex.perc=np.seq )
mu <- link( m5.5 , data=pred.data , n=1e4 )
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )
plot( kcal.per.g ~ neocortex.perc , data=dcc , col=rangi2 )
lines( np.seq , mu.mean )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[1,] , lty=2 )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[2,] , lty=2 )
# The MAP line is weakly positive, but it is highly imprecise. A lot of mildly positive 
# and negative slopes are plausible, given this model and these data.

```

<br>

Now consider another predictor variable, adult female body mass, mass in the data frame.

```{r 5.24}

## Use logarithm of mass, log(mass), as a predictor instead of the raw mass in kilograms
# Taking the log of a measure translates the measure into magnitudes. So by using the 
# logarithm of body mass here, we’re saying that we suspect that the magnitude of a
```
