```{r 5.24}
# mother’s body mass is related to milk energy, in a linear fashion.

# Transforms mass first to make a new column in the data
dcc$log.mass <- log(dcc$mass)

# Fit the model
m5.6 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        kcal.per.g ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bm*log.mass ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bm ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 1 ) ),
    data=dcc )

precis(m5.6)

# Plot the data
np.seq <- -4:5
pred.data <- data.frame( log.mass=np.seq )
mu <- link( m5.6 , data=pred.data , n=1e4 )
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )
plot( kcal.per.g ~ log.mass , data=dcc , col=rangi2 )
lines( np.seq , mu.mean )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[1,] , lty=2 )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[2,] , lty=2 )
# log-mass is negatively correlated with kilocalories. This influence does seem stronger than 
# that of neocortex percent, although in the opposite direction. It is quite uncertain though, 
# with a wide confidence interval that is consistent with a wide range of both weak and 
# stronger relationships.

```

<br>

Now let’s see what happens when we add both predictor variables at the same time to the regression. This is the multivariate model, in math form:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}k_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_n n_i + \beta_m log(m_i)\\\alpha &\sim Normal(0, 100)\\\beta_n &\sim Normal(0, 1)\\\beta_m &\sim Normal(0, 1)\\\sigma &\sim Uniform(0, 10)\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

```
k   = kcal.per.g

n   = neocortex.perc

m   = mass

```

```{r 5.26}

# Fit the joint model
m5.7 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        kcal.per.g ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bn*neocortex.perc + bm*log.mass ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bn ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
        bm ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 1 )
),
data=dcc )

precis(m5.7)
# By incorporating both predictor variables in the regression, the estimated association 
# of both with the outcome has increased. The posterior mean for the association of 
# neocortex percent has increased more than sixfold, and its 89% interval is now entirely 
# above zero. The posterior mean for log body mass is more strongly negative.

## Plot the the intervals for the predicted mean kilocalories
## For necortex.perc
# Use mean log body mass because they are counterfactual plots showing only how predicted 
# energy varies as a function of neocortex percent
mean.log.mass <- mean( log(dcc$mass) ) 
np.seq <- 0:100
pred.data <- data.frame(
    neocortex.perc=np.seq,
    log.mass=mean.log.mass
)
mu <- link( m5.7 , data=pred.data , n=1e4 )
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )
plot( kcal.per.g ~ neocortex.perc , data=dcc , type="n" )
lines( np.seq , mu.mean )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[1,] , lty=2 )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[2,] , lty=2 )

## For log(mass)
mean.neocortex.perc <- mean(dcc$neocortex.perc)
np.seq <- -3:5
pred.data <- data.frame(
    neocortex.perc=mean.neocortex.perc,
    log.mass=np.seq
)
mu <- link( m5.7 , data=pred.data , n=1e4 )
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )
plot( kcal.per.g ~ log.mass , data=dcc , type="n" )
lines( np.seq , mu.mean )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[1,] , lty=2 )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[2,] , lty=2 )

```

<br>

<span style="color:purple">***Why did adding neocortex and body mass to the same model lead to larger estimated effects of both?***</span> 

- There are two variables correlated with the outcome, but one is positively correlated with it and the other is negatively correlated with it. 

- Both of the explanatory variables are positively correlated with one another. As a result, they tend to cancel one another out.

- This is another case in which regression automatically finds the most revealing cases and uses them to produce estimates. What the regression model does is ask if species that have high neocortex percent for their body mass have higher milk energy.

- Likewise, the model asks if species with high body mass for their neocortex percent have higher milk energy. Bigger species, like apes, have milk with less energy. But species with more neocortex tend to have richer milk. 

- The fact that these two variables, body size and neocortex, are correlated across species makes it hard to see these relationships, unless we statistically account for both.

<br>

<span style="color:green">***Compound figure for milk energy and neocortex among primates***</span>

In the top two plots, simple bivariate regressions of kilocalories per gram of milk on (left) neocortex percent and (right) log female body mass show weak and uncertain associations. 

However, on the bottom, a single regression with both neocortex percent and log body mass suggests strong association with both variables. Both neocortex and body mass are associated with milk energy, but in opposite directions. This masks each variable’s relationship with the outcome, unless both are considered simultaneously.

```{r 5.7cf, echo=FALSE}

par(mfrow = c(2,2), mar = c(4,4,4,4))
# Fig 1
np.seq <- 0:100
pred.data <- data.frame( neocortex.perc=np.seq )
mu <- link( m5.5 , data=pred.data , n=1e4 )
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )
plot( kcal.per.g ~ neocortex.perc , data=dcc , col=rangi2 )
lines( np.seq , mu.mean )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[1,] , lty=2 )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[2,] , lty=2 )

# Fig 2
dcc$log.mass <- log(dcc$mass)
m5.6 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        kcal.per.g ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bm*log.mass ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bm ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 1 ) ),
    data=dcc )
np.seq <- -4:5
pred.data <- data.frame( log.mass=np.seq )
mu <- link( m5.6 , data=pred.data , n=1e4 )
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )
plot( kcal.per.g ~ log.mass , data=dcc , col=rangi2 )
lines( np.seq , mu.mean )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[1,] , lty=2 )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[2,] , lty=2 )

# Fig 3
mean.log.mass <- mean( log(dcc$mass) ) 
np.seq <- 0:100
pred.data <- data.frame(
    neocortex.perc=np.seq,
    log.mass=mean.log.mass
)
mu <- link( m5.7 , data=pred.data , n=1e4 )
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )
plot( kcal.per.g ~ neocortex.perc , data=dcc , type="n" )
lines( np.seq , mu.mean )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[1,] , lty=2 )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[2,] , lty=2 )

# Fig 4
mean.neocortex.perc <- mean(dcc$neocortex.perc)
np.seq <- -3:5
pred.data <- data.frame(
    neocortex.perc=mean.neocortex.perc,
    log.mass=np.seq
)
mu <- link( m5.7 , data=pred.data , n=1e4 )
mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI )
plot( kcal.per.g ~ log.mass , data=dcc , type="n" )
lines( np.seq , mu.mean )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[1,] , lty=2 )
lines( np.seq , mu.PI[2,] , lty=2 )

```

<br>

<span style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Simulating a masking relationship**</span>

It may help to simulate data in which two meaningful predictors act to mask one another. Suppose again a single outcome, y, and two predictors, x~pos~ and x~neg~. The predictor x~pos~ is positively associated with y, while x~neg~ is negatively associated with y. Furthermore, the two predictors are positively correlated with one another. 

```{r 5.28}

N <- 100                              # number of cases

rho <- 0.7                            # correlation btw x_pos and x_neg

x_pos <- rnorm(N)                     # x_pos Gaussian

x_neg <- rnorm(N, rho*x_pos,          # x_neg correlated with x_pos
               sqrt(1-rho^2))

y <- rnorm(N, x_pos - x_neg)          # y equally associated with x_pos, x_neg

d <- data.frame(y, x_pos, x_neg)      # bind all together in data frame

pairs(d, main = "(a) Rho = 0.7")
# Predicting y using either x_pos or x_neg gives posterior distributions that underestimate 
# the true association (which should be about 1 or −1, respectively). 
# Fitting a model predicting y using both predictors gives a posterior distribution that 
# better matches the underlying truth.

## Move rho closer to 0
N <- 100                              
rho <- 0.1                          
x_pos <- rnorm(N)                    
x_neg <- rnorm(N, rho*x_pos,          
               sqrt(1-rho^2))
y <- rnorm(N, x_pos - x_neg)         
d <- data.frame(y, x_pos, x_neg)  
pairs(d, main = "(b) Rho closer to zero")
# If you move the value of rho closer to zero, this masking phenomenon will diminish.

## Make rho closer to 1
N <- 100                              
rho <- 0.99                         
x_pos <- rnorm(N)                    
x_neg <- rnorm(N, rho*x_pos,          
               sqrt(1-rho^2))
y <- rnorm(N, x_pos - x_neg)         
d <- data.frame(y, x_pos, x_neg)  
pairs(d, main = "(c) Rho closer to 1")

## Make rho closer to -1
N <- 100                              
rho <- -0.99                         
x_pos <- rnorm(N)                    
x_neg <- rnorm(N, rho*x_pos,          
               sqrt(1-rho^2))
y <- rnorm(N, x_pos - x_neg)         
d <- data.frame(y, x_pos, x_neg)  
pairs(d, main = "(d) Rho closer to -1")
# If you make rho closer to 1 or −1, the masking relationship will magnify. 
# But if rho gets very close to 1 or −1, then the two predictors contain exactly 
# the same information, and there’s no hope for any statistical model to tease out 
# the true underlying association used in the simulation.

```

<br>

<span style="color:purple">***Why should two predictors be correlated in this way?***</span>

- They might both be influenced by another, unmeasured variable. 

- Or one of them, say x~neg~, is influenced partly by x~pos~, but also by its own unique processes. 

- They might both partly influence one another, in a case of reciprocal causation.

<br>

## When adding variables hurts

It is commonly true that there are many potential predictor variables to add to a regression model. Why not just fit a model that includes all potential predictor variables? There are several good, purely statistical reasons to avoid doing this. Three of them are:

- Multicollinearity
    - very strong correlation between two or more predictor variables. 
    - The consequence of it is that the posterior distribution will say that a very large range of parameter values are plausible, from tiny associations to massive ones, even if all of the variables are in reality strongly associated with the outcome variable.
    
\n

- Post-treatment bias
    - statistically controlling for consequences of a causal factor.
    
\n

- Overfitting
    - a huge and perspective-changing problem
    
<br>

### Multicollinear legs

The simulation example is predicting an individual’s height using the length of his or her legs as predictor variables. Surely height is positively associated with leg length, or at least the simulation will assume it is. Nevertheless, once you put both leg lengths into the model, something vexing will happen.

```{r 5.29}

set.seed(4)

## Simulate the heights and leg lengths of 100 individuals

N <- 100                           # number of individuals

# For each, first a height is simulated from a Gaussian distribution
height <- rnorm(N, 10, 2)         # sim total height of each

# Each individual gets a simulated proportion of height for their legs, ranging from 0.4 to 0.5
leg_prop <- runif(N, 0.4, 0.5)    # leg as proportion of height

# Each leg is salted with a little measurement or developmental error, so the left and right legs 
# are not exactly the same length, as is typical in real populations
leg_left <- leg_prop*height +     # sim left leg as proportion + error
  rnorm(N, 0, 0.02)

leg_right <- leg_prop*height +    # sim right leg as proportion + error 
  rnorm(N, 0, 0.02)

d <- data.frame(height, leg_left, # combine into data frame
                leg_right)

pairs(d, col = "pink")
```

On average, an individual’s legs are 45% of his or her height (in these simulated data). So we should expect the beta coefficient that measures the association of a leg with height to end up around the average height (10) divided by 45% of the average height (4.5). This is 10/4.5 ≈ 2.2. Now let’s see what happens instead:

```{r 5.30}

m5.8 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        height ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bl*leg_left + br*leg_right ,
        a ~ dnorm( 10 , 100 ) ,
        bl ~ dnorm( 2 , 10 ) ,
        br ~ dnorm( 2 , 10 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 )
),
    data=d )

precis(m5.8)

plot(precis(m5.8))

```

If both legs have almost identical lengths, and height is so strongly associated with leg length, then why is this posterior distribution so weird? Did the model fitting work correctly? The question for the model to answer is: *What is the value of knowing each leg’s length, after already knowing the other leg’s length?* 

The model did fit correctly. The posterior distribution is the answer to this question, considering every possible combination of the parameters and assigning relative plausibilities to every combination, conditional on this model and these data.

```{r 5.32}
set.seed(35)
# Take a look at the bivariate posterior distribution for bl and br
post <- extract.samples(m5.8)
plot( bl ~ br , post , col=col.alpha(rangi2,0.1) , pch=16 )
# Posterior distribution of the association of each leg with height, from model m5.8. 
# Since both variables contain almost identical information, the posterior is a narrow 
# ridge of negatively correlated values.

```

<br>

One way to think of this phenomenon is that you have approximated this likelihood:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}y_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_1 x_i + \beta_2 x_i\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

```
y   = outcome (height)

x   = single predictor (leg lengths)

```

Here x is used twice, which is a perfect example of the problem caused by using the almost-identical leg lengths. From the computer’s perspective, this likelihood is really:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}y_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + (\beta_1 + \beta_2) x_i\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

This means the posterior distribution ends up reporting the practically infinite combinations of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\beta_1}" title="" /> and <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\beta_2}" title="" /> that make their sum close to the actual association of x with y.

```{r 5.33}

# Compute the posterior distribution of the sum of bl and br
sum_blbr <- post$bl + post$br

precis(sum_blbr)
# The posterior mean is in the right neighborhood, around 2, and the standard deviation 
# is much smaller than it is for either component of the sum, bl or br.

# Plot the posterior distribution 
dens( sum_blbr , col=rangi2 , lwd=2 , xlab="sum of bl and br" )
# The posterior distribution of the sum of the two parameters is centered on the 
# proper association of either leg with height.

```

If you fit a regression with only one of the leg length variables, you’ll get approximately the same posterior mean:

```{r 5.34}
par(mfrow = c(1,2))
set.seed(36)
m5.9 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        height ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bl*leg_left,
        a ~ dnorm( 10 , 100 ) ,
        bl ~ dnorm( 2 , 10 ) ,
sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 ) ),
    data=d )

precis(m5.9)
# 1.94 is almost identical to the mean value of sum_blbr.

plot(precis(m5.9), main = "Left leg")

## For right leg
m5.9b <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        height ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + br*leg_right,
        a ~ dnorm( 10 , 100 ) ,
        br ~ dnorm( 2 , 10 ) ,
sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 ) ),
    data=d )

precis(m5.9b)
plot(precis(m5.9b), main = "Right leg")

```

***When two predictor variables are very strongly correlated, including both in a model may lead to confusion.***

The posterior distribution isn’t wrong, in such cases. It’s telling you that the question you asked cannot be answered with these data. And that’s a great thing for a model to say, that it cannot answer your question. And if you are just interested in prediction, you’ll find that this leg model makes fine predictions. It just doesn’t make any claims about which leg is more important.

<br>

### Multicollinear milk

In the leg length example, it’s easy to see that including both legs in the model is a little silly. But the problem that arises in real data sets is that we may not anticipate a clash between highly correlated predictors. And therefore we may mistakenly read the posterior distribution to say that neither predictor is important.

```{r 5.35}

### Look at the issue with real data

# Load milk data
data(milk)
d <- milk

## Start by modeling kcal.per.g as a function of perc.fat and perc.lactose, 
## but in two bivariate regressions
# kcal.per.g regressed on perc.fat
m5.10 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        kcal.per.g ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bf*perc.fat ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0.6 , 10 ) ,
        bf ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 )
),
data=d )

# kcal.per.g regressed on perc.lactose
m5.11 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        kcal.per.g ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bl*perc.lactose ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0.6 , 10 ) ,
        bl ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 )
), data=d )

precis( m5.10 , digits=3 )
# The posterior mean for bf, the association of percent fat with milk energy, is 0.01, 
# with 89% interval [0.008, 0.012].

precis( m5.11 , digits=3 )
# The posterior mean in the second model for percent lactose is −0.01, 
# with 89% interval [−0.012, −0.009].

# These posterior means are essentially mirror images of one another, with the posterior mean 
# of bf being as positive as the mean of bl is negative. Both are narrow posterior 
# distributions that lie almost entirely on one side or the other of zero.

# Note the parameter values for the slopes bf and bl are small in absolute value.
# Both predictors are percents, so are potentially large numbers- these associations really 
# have much influence on the outcome, milk energy. Given the strong association of each 
# predictor with the outcome, we might conclude that both variables are reliable predictors 
# of total energy in milk, across species. 

## Place both predictor variables in the same regression model
m5.12 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
      kcal.per.g ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bf*perc.fat + bl*perc.lactose ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0.6 , 10 ) ,
        bf ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
        bl ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 )
),
    data=d )

precis( m5.12 , digits=3 )
# Now the posterior means of both bf and bl are closer to zero. And the standard deviations 
# for both parameters are twice as large as in the bivariate models (m5.10 and m5.11). 
# In the case of percent fat, the posterior mean is essentially zero.

# What has happened is that the variables perc.fat and perc.lactose contain much of the 
# same information. They are substitutes for one another. As a result, when you include both 
# in a regression, the posterior distribution ends up describing a long ridge of combinations 
# of bf and bl that are equally plausible.

# See results with pairs plot
pairs( ~ kcal.per.g + perc.fat + perc.lactose ,
    data=d , col=rangi2 )
# A pairs plot of the total energy, percent fat, and percent lactose variables from the primate 
# milk data. Percent fat and percent lactose are strongly negatively correlated with one another, 
# providing mostly the same information- these two variables form essentially a single axis of variation.
# These two variables are negatively correlated, and so strongly so that they are nearly redundant. 
# Either helps in predicting kcal.per.g, but neither helps much once you already know the other.

# Compute the correlation between the two variables with cor
cor( d$perc.fat , d$perc.lactose )


```

<br>

Correlations do have to get pretty high before this problem interferes with your analysis. But, ***what matters isn’t just the correlation between a pair of variables. Rather, what matters is the correlation that remains after accounting for any other predictors.***

But with only two predictors here, we can address the correlation question directly. Suppose we have only kcal.per.g and perc.fat:

```{r 5.10a}

# Construct a random predictor variable, call it x, that is correlated with perc.fat 
# at some predetermined level
N <- nrow(milk)
rho <- 0.6
x <- rnorm(N, rho*milk$perc.fat, sqrt(1 - rho^2))
kcal.per.g <- rnorm(N, milk$perc.fat - x)
d <- data.frame(kcal.per.g, milk$perc.fat, x)

pairs(d, col = "red")

# Fit the regression model that tries to predict kcal.per.g using both perc.fat 
# and our random fake variable x
m5.10a <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    kcal.per.g ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + bf*milk$perc.fat + bx*x,
    a ~ dnorm(0.4, 10),
    bf ~ dnorm(0, 1),
    bx ~ dnorm(0, 1),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
  ),
  data = d
)

precis(m5.10a, digits = 3)

```

Now repeat this procedure many times, at different levels of correlation between perc.fat and x:

```{r 5.40}

data(milk)
d <- milk
sim.coll <- function( r=0.9 ) {
    d$x <- rnorm( nrow(d) , mean=r*d$perc.fat ,
        sd=sqrt( (1-r^2)*var(d$perc.fat) ) )
    m <- lm( kcal.per.g ~ perc.fat + x , data=d )
    sqrt( diag( vcov(m) ) )[2] # stddev of parameter
}
rep.sim.coll <- function( r=0.9 , n=100 ) { # 100 regressions
    stddev <- replicate( n , sim.coll(r) )
    mean(stddev)
}
r.seq <- seq(from=0,to=0.99,by=0.01)
stddev <- sapply( r.seq , function(z) rep.sim.coll(r=z,n=100) )
plot( stddev ~ r.seq , type="l" , col=rangi2, lwd=2 , xlab="correlation" )
# The effect of correlated predictor variables on the narrowness of the posterior distribution. 
# The vertical axis shows the standard deviation of the posterior distribution of the slope. 
# The horizontal axis is the correlation between the predictor of interest (perc.fat) and another
# predictor (x) added to the model. As the correlation increases, the standard deviation inflates.

```

<br>

<span style="color:purple">***What can be done about multicollinearity***</span>

- Be aware of it.

- Check the predictor variables against one another in a pairs plot.
    - Any pair or cluster of variables with very large correlations, over about 0.9, may be problematic, once included as main effects in the same model.
    - However, it isn’t always true that highly correlated variables are completely redundant— other predictors might be correlated with only one of the pair, and so help extract the unique information each predictor provides.
    - So, you can’t know just from a table of correlations nor from a matrix of scatterplots whether multicollinearity will prevent you from including sets of variables in the same model.
    - Still, you can usually diagnose the problem by looking for a big inflation of standard deviation, when both variables are included in the same model.
    
\n

- Principle components or Factor analysis
    - A data reduction procedure, and then to use the components/factors as predictor variables
    - may be considered voodoo
    
\n

- ***It’s usually helpful to check the covariation among parameters, especially when intervals are extremely wide, so you don’t misinterpret what the model is trying to tell you.***

<br>

### Post-treatment bias

- Omitted variable bias
    - mistaken inferences that arise from omitting predictor variables
    
\n

- Post-treatment bias
    - mistaken inferences arising from including variables that are consequences of other variables
    
<br>

Simulate post-treatment bias in plant growth vs. different anti-fungal soil treatments model. There are four variables of interest here: initial height, final height, treatment, and presence of fungus. Final height is the outcome of interest. But which of the other variables should be in the model? If your goal is to make a causal inference about the treatment, you shouldn’t include the presence of fungus, because it is a post-treatment effect.

```{r 5.41}

set.seed(54)
# number of plants
N <- 100

# simulate initial heights
h0 <- rnorm(N,10,2)

# assign treatments and simulate fungus and growth
treatment <- rep( 0:1 , each=N/2 )
fungus <- rbinom( N , size=1 , prob=0.5 - treatment*0.4 )
h1 <- h0 + rnorm(N, 5 - 3*fungus)

# compose a clean data frame
d <- data.frame( h0=h0 , h1=h1 , treatment=treatment , fungus=fungus )
str(d)

# fit the model that includes all of the available variables
m5.13 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        h1 ~ dnorm(mu,sigma),
        mu <- a + bh*h0 + bt*treatment + bf*fungus,
        a ~ dnorm(0,100),
        c(bh,bt,bf) ~ dnorm(0,10),
        sigma ~ dunif(0,10)
),
    data=d )

precis(m5.13)

```

The marginal posterior for bt, the effect of treatment, is actually negative here. But it mainly had very little effect. The other two predictors, h0 and fungus, have important effects. Given that we know the treatment matters, because we built the simulation that way, what happened here? The problem is that fungus is mostly a consequence of treatment- fungus is a post-treatment variable. When we control for fungus, the soil treatment doesn't matter because soil treatment has its effects on growth through reducing fungus. 

*Model m5.13 misleads because it asks the wrong question, not because it would make poor predictions- the model that includes fungus both fits the sample better and would make better out-of-sample predictions. No statistical procedure can substitute for scientific knowledge and attention to it.*
    
What we actually want to know, based on the design of the experiment, is the impact of treatment on growth. To measure this properly, we should omit the post-treatment variable fungus. 

```{r 5.43}
set.seed(43)
m5.14 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        h1 ~ dnorm(mu,sigma),
        mu <- a + bh*h0 + bt*treatment,
        a ~ dnorm(0,100),
        c(bh,bt) ~ dnorm(0,10),
        sigma ~ dunif(0,10)
),
    data=d )

precis(m5.14)
# Now the impact of treatment is strong and positive, as it should be. It makes sense to 
# control for pre-treatment differences, like the initial height h0, that might mask the 
# causal influence of treatment. But including post-treatment variables can actually mask 
# the treatment itself.

```

<br>

## Categorical variables

A common question for statistical methods is to what extent an outcome changes as a result of presence or absence of a category. Common examples of categorical variables (factors) include:

- Sex: male, female

- Developmental status: infant, juvenile, adult

- Geographic region: Africa, Europe, Melanesia

- Taxonomic group: Ape, Monkeys

<br>

### Binary categories

In the simplest case, the variable of interest has only two categories, like male and female. 

```{r 5.44}

# Load data Howell1
data(Howell1)
d <- Howell1
str(d)
# The male variable is our new predictor, an example of a dummy variable.
# Dummy variables are devices for encoding categories into quantitative models.
# e.g. 1 for male, 0 for female

```

The effect of a dummy variable is to turn a parameter on for those cases in the category. Simultaneously, the variable turns the same parameter off for those cases in another category. The model to fit is:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}h_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_m m_i\\\alpha &\sim Normal(178, 100)\\\beta_m &\sim Normal(0, 10)\\\sigma &\sim Uniform(0, 50)\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

```
h   = height

m   = dummy variable indicating a male individual

```

The parameter <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\beta_m}" title="" /> influences prediction only for those cases where <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{m_i}" title="" /> = 1. When <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{m_i}" title="" /> = 0, it has no effect on prediction, because it is multiplied by zero inside the linear model, <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\alpha + \beta_m m_i}" title="" />, canceling it out, whatever its value.

```{r 5.45}

# Fit the model
m5.15 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        height ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bm*male , 
        a ~ dnorm( 178 , 100 ) ,
        bm ~ dnorm( 0 , 10 ) ,
sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 50 ) ),
    data=d )

precis(m5.15)
# The parameter α (a) is now the average height among females. Because when mi = 0, 
# indicating a female, the predicted mean height is just μi = α + βm(0) = α. 
# So the estimate says that the expected average female height is 135 cm. 
# The parameter βm then tells us the average difference between males and females, 7.3 cm. 
# So to compute the average male height, you just add these two estimates: 135 + 7.3 = 142.3.

# You’ll also need to consider the width of the posterior distribution. And because the 
# parameters α and βm are correlated with one another, you can’t just add together 
# the boundaries in the precis output and get correct boundaries for their sum. 

# Sample from the posterior to derive a percentile interval for average male height
post <- extract.samples(m5.15)

# Add samples of a and bm together to get the posterior distribution of their sum
mu.male <- post$a + post$bm
PI(mu.male)

```

<br>

<span style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Re-parameterizing the model**</span></span>

Instead of using a parameter for the difference between males and females, we can make parameters specific to males and females:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}h_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha_f(1 - m_i) + \alpha_m m_i\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

```
alpha_f   = average female height

alpha_m   = average male height

```

Plug in <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{m_i}" title="" /> = 0 and <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{m_i}" title="" /> = 1 to verify that either <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\alpha_f}" title="" /> or <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\alpha_m}" title="" />, but never both, is turned on for any individual case i. 

```{r 5.47}

# Fit the model
m5.15b <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        height ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- af*(1-male) + am*male ,
        af ~ dnorm( 178 , 100 ) ,
        am ~ dnorm( 178 , 100 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 50 )
), data=d )

precis(m5.15b)
# The results are inferentially equivalent to the original m5.15.

```

The mathematical model can be rearranged where the old <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\beta_m}" title="" /> as the difference between the average male and female, <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\alpha_m - \alpha_f}" title="" />:

![](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\boldsymbol{\mu_i = \alpha_f + (\alpha_m - \alpha_f) m_i})

<br>

### Many categories

When there are more than two categories, you’ll need more than one dummy variable. To include k categories in a linear model, you require k − 1 dummy variables. Each dummy variable indicates, with the value 1, a unique category. The category with no dummy variable assigned to it ends up again as the “intercept” category.

```{r 5.48}

# Load milk data and extract clade variable
data(milk)
d <- milk
unique(d$clade)
# There are more than two categories and none of them have yet been coded into dummy variables.

# Create a dummy for the New World Monkey category
( d$clade.NWM <- ifelse( d$clade=="New World Monkey" , 1 , 0 ) )
# Only those rows (cases) where clade is New World Monkey get a 1 for this new variable.

# Make two more dummy variables with the same strategy
d$clade.OWM <- ifelse( d$clade=="Old World Monkey" , 1 , 0 )
d$clade.S <- ifelse( d$clade=="Strepsirrhine" , 1 , 0 )

```

<br>

The category `Ape` will be the default "intercept" category. In fact, if you try to include a dummy variable for apes, you’ll up with a non-identifiable model. 

The model we aim to fit to the data is kcal.per.g regressed on the dummy variables for clade:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}k_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_{NWM} NWM_i + \beta_{OWM} OWM_i + \beta_S S_i\\\alpha &\sim Normal(0.6, 10)\\\beta_{NWM} &\sim Normal(0, 1)\\\beta_{OWM} &\sim Normal(0, 1)\\\beta_S &\sim Normal(0, 1)\\\sigma &\sim Uniform(0, 10)\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

A linear model like this really defines four different linear models, each corresponding to a different category.

```{r 5.51}

## Fit the model
m5.16 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        kcal.per.g ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + b.NWM*clade.NWM + b.OWM*clade.OWM + b.S*clade.S ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0.6 , 10 ) ,
        b.NWM ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
        b.OWM ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
        b.S ~ dnorm( 0 , 1 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 )
),
    data=d )

precis(m5.16)
# The estimate a is the average milk energy for apes, and the estimates for the other 
# categories are differences from apes.

## Use samples to get posterior distributions of the average milk energy in each category
# sample posterior
post <- extract.samples(m5.16)

# compute averages for each category
mu.ape <- post$a
mu.NWM <- post$a + post$b.NWM
mu.OWM <- post$a + post$b.OWM
mu.S <- post$a + post$b.S

# summarize using precis
precis( data.frame(mu.ape,mu.NWM,mu.OWM,mu.S) )
# The most plausible (conditional on data and model) average milk energies in each category 
# are 0.55, 0.71, 0.79, and 0.51.

## Re-parameterize model after fitting it to data to know the estimate difference between
## two monkey groups- rather than a difference from apes. 
# Substract the estimated means to get a difference
diff.NWM.OWM <- mu.NWM - mu.OWM
quantile( diff.NWM.OWM , probs=c(0.025,0.5,0.975) )
# The values are the posterior lower 95% boundary, the median, and the upper 95% boundary 
# for the difference between New World and Old World monkeys.

```

<br>

### Adding regular predictor variables

Just add the predictor variables to the equation for the mean, as you normally would. For example, to add the influence of perc.fat to the model with dummies for the clades:

![](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\boldsymbol{\mu_i = \alpha + \beta_{NWM} NWM_i + \beta_{OWM} OWM_i + \beta_S S_i + \beta_F F_i})

```
Fi    = the percent fat for the i-th case in the data 

βF    = the slope that measures the influence of F on predictions about the mean milk energy.

```

<br>

### Another approach: Unique intercepts

Another way to conceptualize categorical variables is to construct a vector of intercept parameters, one parameter for each category. Then you can create an ***index variable*** in your data frame that says which parameter goes with each case.

```{r 5.54}

# Make an index variable for clade in the primate milk data
( d$clade_id <- coerce_index(d$clade) )
# This variable just gives the number of each unique clade value. There are four different clades, 
# and it doesn’t matter which is “1” or “4,” because they are unordered.

# Use map to make a vector of intercepts, one intercept for each unique value in clade_id
m5.16_alt <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        kcal.per.g ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a[clade_id] ,
        a[clade_id] ~ dnorm( 0.6 , 10 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 10 )
),
    data=d )

precis( m5.16_alt , depth=2 )
# Same averages for each clade as earlier (m5.16), but this time directly from the fit model.
# Need to add depth=2 to the precis call in order to print out vector parameters like these.

```

<br>

## Ordinary least squares and `lm`

Gaussian regression models or ordinary least squares regression (OLS) is a way of estimating the parameters of a linear regression. Instead of searching for the combination of parameter values that maximizes the posterior probability, OLS instead solves for the parameter values that minimize the sum of the squared residuals. This procedure is often functionally equivalent to maximizing the posterior probability or maximizing the likelihood. *Provided you are happy with flat priors, you’ll get the same estimates with `lm` that you got with `map`.*

<br>

### Design formulas

Design formulas (input format for models) take the expression for <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu_i}" title="" /> in the detailed mathematical form of a model and strip out the parameters, leaving only a series of predictor names, separated by + signs. These formulas are sufficient to describe the model’s design, provided all priors are flat.

The linear regression model:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}y_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta x_i\\\end{align*}" title="" />


<br>

The corresponding design formula with the leading 1 on the right-hand side indicates the intercept, <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\alpha}" title="" />:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}y \sim 1 + x\\\end{align*}" title="" />


<br> 

The linear regression model with three predictors:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}y_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_x x_i + \beta_z Z_i + \beta_w W_i\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

The corresponding design formula:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}y \sim 1 + x + z + w\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

### Using `lm`

To fit a linear regression using OLS, just provide the design formula and the name of the data frame.

```{r 5.56}

y <- c(1,2,2,3)
x <- c(2,1,1,1)
z <- c(4,4,4,4)
w <- c(2,2,2,2)
d <- data.frame(y, x, z, w)
# For first example above
m5.17 <- lm( y ~ 1 + x , data=d ) # assume data are in a frame named d

# For second example above
m5.18 <- lm( y ~ 1 + x + z + w , data=d )
# The parameter estimates will be named after the predictors, since you didn’t provide any 
# explicit parameter names. You can sample from the posterior and process estimates as usual.

```

<br>

#### Intercepts are optional

These two model fits return exactly the same estimates:

```{r 5.57}

m5.17 <- lm( y ~ 1 + x , data=d )
m5.19 <- lm( y ~ x , data=d )

# Test with milk data
data(milk)
d <- milk
m5.17a <- lm(milk$kcal.per.g ~ 1 + milk$perc.protein, data = d)
m5.18a <- lm(milk$kcal.per.g ~  milk$perc.protein, data = d)

precis(m5.17a)
precis(m5.18a)

```

When you omit the explicit intercept, `lm` assumes you wanted one. If you really do not want an intercept&mdash; equivalent to fixing <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\alpha = 0}" title="" />&mdash; then you can use one of these forms:

```{r 5.58}

m5.20 <- lm( y ~ 0 + x , data=d )
m5.21 <- lm( y ~ x - 1 , data=d )

# Test with milk data
m5.20a <- lm(milk$kcal.per.g ~ 0 + milk$perc.protein)
m5.21a <- lm(milk$kcal.per.g ~ milk$perc.protein - 1)

precis(m5.20a)
precis(m5.21a)

```

<br>

#### Categorical variables

Black-box functions like `lm` will automatically expand categorical factors into the necessary number of dummy variables. But R is not a mind reader, and sometimes the same variable can be treated as categories or rather as continuous. To prevent R from getting confused, and therefore confusing yourself, best to get into the habit of explicitly telling lm when you mean to use a variable as categories.

```{r 5.59}

# R can think seasons (1,2,3,4) as categorical (different seasons) or 
# continuous variable marking the passage of time
season <- c(1,2,3,4)

# Tell R to use variable as categories
m5.22 <- lm( y ~ 1 + as.factor(season) , data=d )
# The function as.factor makes sure that lm knows to treat the values in season 
# as unordered categories.

```

<br>

#### Transform variables first

Black-box functions like `lm` sometimes have problems understanding the transformations(logarithms, squares, cubes, centering, standardizing), when they are included in the design formula. So it’s best to make new variables that hold the transformed values. Then include those new variables instead.

```{r 5.60}

# Make up a data frame d to run the code
d <- data.frame(x = seq(-5, 5, by = 1), y =seq(-5, 5, by =1))

# Fit a cubic regression of y on x
d$x2 <- d$x^2
d$x3 <- d$x^3
m5.23 <- lm( y ~ 1 + x + x2 + x3 , data=d )

# Use 'as is' function I() to fit the same cubic model
# Note that I() can't be used inside map 
m5.24 <- lm( y ~ 1 + x + I(x^2) + I(x^3) , data=d )

```

<br>

#### No estimate for <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\sigma}" title="" />

Using `lm` will not provide a posterior distribution for the standard deviation <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\sigma}" title="" />&mdash; it won’t be reported in the table of estimates. If you ask for a summary of the model fit, `lm` will report the “residual standard error,” which is a slightly different estimate of <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\sigma}" title="" />, but without any uncertainty information like a standard deviation (or standard error).

Use `map` if you need <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\sigma}" title="" />&mdash; get some sense of the uncertainty of the estimate. As a bonus, you can use informative priors then, as well.

<br>

### Building `map` formulas from `lm` formulas

The `rethinking` package provides a function, `glimmer`, that translates design formulas into `map`&mdash; style model formulas.

```{r 5.62}

data(cars)
glimmer( dist ~ speed , data=cars )

# The function glimmer automatically adds default priors. You can change these to suit your 
# tastes, or remove them all together, if you just want maximum likelihood estimation. 

```

<br>

## Summary

The defining question of multiple regression is: 

![\large](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\textit{\textbf{What is the value of knowing each predictor, once we already know the other predictors?}})

Implicit in this question are: 

(1) a focus on the value of the predictors for description of the sample, instead of forecasting a future sample

(2) the assumption that the value of each predictor does not depend upon the values of the other predictors

<br>

## Practice

### Easy

<br>

> 5E1. Which of the linear models below are multiple linear regressions?

(2) ![](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\boldsymbol{\mu_i = \beta_x x_i + \beta_z Z_i})
(4) ![](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\boldsymbol{\mu_i = \alpha + \beta_x x_i + \beta_z Z_i})

<br>

> 5E2. Write down a multiple regression to evaluate the claim: Animal diversity is linearly related to latitude, but only after controlling for plant diversity. You just need to write down the model definition.

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}AD_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_L L_i + \beta_D D_i\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

```
AD    = Animal diversity

L     = Latitude

D     = Plant diversity

```

<br>

> 5E3. Write down a multiple regression to evaluate the claim: Neither amount of funding nor size of laboratory is by itself a good predictor of time to PhD degree; but together these variables are both positively associated with time to degree. Write down the model definition and indicate which side of zero each slope parameter should be on.


<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}T_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_F F_i + \beta_S S_i\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

```
T   = Time to PhD degree

F   = Amount of funding

S   = Size of laboratory

Both beta_F and beta_S should be on the positive size of zero if considered together.
If considered individually, both will be almost zero. 

```

<br>

> 5E4. Suppose you have a single categorical predictor with 4 levels (unique values), labeled A, B, C and D. Let Ai be an indicator variable that is 1 where case i is in category A. Also suppose Bi, Ci, and Di for the other categories. Now which of the following linear models are inferentially equivalent ways to include the categorical variable in a regression? Models are inferentially equivalent when it’s possible to compute one posterior distribution from the posterior distribution of another model.

I exclude choice 2 as it contains all variables plus one extra unidentified interceptor variable. I use `Accident` dataset to check the similarity among posterior distributions of the models in choices 1, 3, 4, and 5. As seen below, the mean (<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu}" title="" />) values of dummy variables A, B, C and D are similar across the models 1, 3, 4 and 5. Hence, choice 1, 3, 4 and 5 are the correct answers to the question. The slight difference between model 1,3 and model 4,5 is because I used informative priors for model 4 and 5, and flat priors for model 1 and 3. 

```{r 5E4}

par(mfrow = c(2,2), mar = c(4,4,4,4))

# Load data to test the posteriors of each model 
data("Accident")
d <- Accident

# Extract categorical variables
unique(d$type)

# Remove level E because we only need A, B, C, D
dn <- droplevels(d[!d$type == "E", ])
str(dn)

# Extract again
unique(dn$type)

# I want to see correlation between ship type and number of accident
# Check if got NA values in accident
dn$acc

# Drop the 4 NA values
dnc <- dn[complete.cases(dn), ]
dnc$acc

# Make dummy variables for A, B, C, D
# The question doesn't specify which label is the intercept one, so I will do all
dnc$type.A <- ifelse(dnc$type == "A", 1, 0)
dnc$type.B <- ifelse(dnc$type == "B", 1, 0)
dnc$type.C <- ifelse(dnc$type == "C", 1, 0)
dnc$type.D <- ifelse(dnc$type == "D", 1, 0)

# Model 1
m1 <- lm(dnc$acc ~ 1 + type.A + type.B + type.D, data = dnc)
precis(m1)
plot(precis(m1), main = "Model 1")
post1 <- extract.samples(m1)
mu.C <- post1$Intercept
mu.A <- post1$Intercept + post1$type.A
mu.B <- post1$Intercept + post1$type.B
mu.D <- post1$Intercept + post1$type.D
precis(data.frame(mu.A, mu.B, mu.C, mu.D))

# Model 2 is skipped because it contains two intercepts.

# Model 3
m3 <- lm(dnc$acc ~ 1 + type.B + type.C + type.D, data = dnc)
precis(m3)
plot(precis(m3), main = "Model 3")
post3 <- extract.samples(m3)
mu.A <- post3$Intercept
mu.C <- post3$Intercept + post3$type.C
mu.B <- post3$Intercept + post3$type.B
mu.D <- post3$Intercept + post3$type.D
precis(data.frame(mu.A, mu.B, mu.C, mu.D))

# Model 4
m4 <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    acc ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- aA*type.A + aB*type.B + aC*type.C + aD*type.D,
    aA ~ dnorm(5, 5),
    aB ~ dnorm(30, 9),
    aC ~ dnorm(1, 5),
    aD ~ dnorm(2, 5),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
  ),
  data = dnc
)
precis(m4)
plot(precis(m4), main = "Model 4")
post4 <- extract.samples(m4)
mu.A <- post4$aA
mu.B <- post4$aB
mu.C <- post4$aC
mu.D <- post4$aD
precis(data.frame(mu.A, mu.B, mu.C, mu.D))

# Model 5
m5 <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    acc ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- aA*(1 - type.B - type.C - type.D) + aB*type.B + aC*type.C + aD*type.D,
    aA ~ dnorm(5, 5),
    aB ~ dnorm(30, 9),
    aC ~ dnorm(1, 5),
    aD ~ dnorm(2, 5),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
    ),
  data = dnc
)
precis(m5)
post5 <- extract.samples(m5)
mu.A <- post5$aA
mu.B <- post5$aB
mu.C <- post5$aC
mu.D <- post5$aD
precis(data.frame(mu.A, mu.B, mu.C, mu.D))
plot(precis(m5), main = "Model 5")


```

<br>

### Medium

<br>

> 5M1. Invent your own example of a spurious correlation. An outcome variable should be correlated with both predictor variables. But when both predictors are entered in the same model, the correlation between the outcome and one of the predictors should mostly vanish (or at least be greatly reduced).

I invented a data set that contains rate of rainfall (rain.ppt), percent probability of seeing stars in the night sky (chance.star) and percent increase in sales of umbrella (umbrella.sales). The outcome variable `chance.star` and predictor variable `rain.ppt` were fitted in model `m.rs`, and the model predicts the chance of seeing stars would be decreased by 1.4% for every inch of increased rainfall. 

Another predictor variable `umbrella.sales` was fitted to the same outcome variable in model `m.us`, and the model showed the chance of seeing star would be decreased by approximate 1.5% for every percent increase in umbrella sales. So, the correlation between chance of seeing stars and umbrella sales was stronger by about 0.1% when two predictors were put into model separately.

But, when the two predictor variables were fitted together to the outcome variable, the correlation between rate of rain fall and chance of seeing stars remained the same at -1.4%, while the correlation dropped to -0.07% for umbrella sales. 

```{r 5M1}

rain.ppt <- c(0.25, 0.5, 0.3, 0.1, 0.6, 0.4, 0.2, 0.27, 0.33, 0.35)

chance.star <- c(0.6, 0.25, 0.5, 0.9, 0.2, 0.28, 0.7, 0.65, 0.55, 0.52)

umbrella.sales <- c(0.1, 0.05, 0.15, 0.05, 0.3, 0.25, 0.15, 0.13, 0.18, 0.2)

d <- data.frame(rain.ppt, chance.star, umbrella.sales)

str(d)

# Check correlation between rainfall rate and probability of seeing stars
m.rs <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    d$chance.star ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + bR * d$rain.ppt,
    a ~ dnorm(0, 1),
    bR ~ dnorm(0, 1),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
  ),
  data = d
)
precis(m.rs)
d1 <- ggplot(d, aes(x = rain.ppt, y = chance.star)) +
  geom_point(color = col.alpha("firebrick3", 0.8), size = 2) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", fullrange = T,
              color  = "firebrick4", size = 1/2, 
              fill   = "firebrick1", alpha = 1/3) +
  labs(x = "Rate of rainfall", y = "Chance of seeing stars") +
  theme_bw() 

# Check correlation between umbrella sales and probability of seeing stars
m.us <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    d$chance.star ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + bU * d$umbrella.sales,
    a ~ dnorm(0, 1),
    bU ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
  ),
  data = d
)
precis(m.us)
d2 <- ggplot(d, aes(x = umbrella.sales, y = chance.star)) +
  geom_point(color = col.alpha("#73a5c6", 0.8), size = 2) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", fullrange = T,
              color  = "#528aae", size = 1/2, 
              fill   = "#bcd2e8", alpha = 1/3) +
  labs(x = "Percent increase in umbrella sales", y = "Chance of seeing stars") +
  theme_bw() 
 grid.arrange(d1, d2, ncol = 2)
 

 # Consider both predictors to the outcome
 m.b <- rethinking::map(
   alist(
     d$chance.star ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
     mu <- a + bR * d$rain.ppt + bU * d$umbrella.sales,
     a ~ dnorm(0, 1),
     bR ~ dnorm(0, 1),
     bU ~ dnorm(0, 10),
     sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
   ),
   data = d
 )
precis(m.b)
pairs(~ chance.star + rain.ppt + umbrella.sales, data = d, col = "firebrick")

```

<br>

> 5M2. Invent your own example of a masked relationship. An outcome variable should be correlated with both predictor variables, but in opposite directions. And the two predictor variables should be correlated with one another.

Instead of adjusting each data point to get the desired relationship (like in 5M1 which took quite a while to manipulate the data), I used the book's code to create a data set for simulating a masked relationship. In the example below, the number of trees in the area (`tree.number`) is positively associated with good air quality (`pm.air`), while the number of factory in the area (`factory.number`) is negatively associated with good air quality(`pm.air`). The `factory.number` and `tree.number` have a correlation strength of 0.5.

When the predictors are fitted separately to the model, the <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\beta}" title="" /> coefficients for `tree.number` and `factory.number` are 0.52 and -0.47, in relation to the outcome `pm.air`. But when the predictors are fitted together in the model, stronger associations with outcome variable are seen with each of the predictors (0.99 for `tree.number` and -0.97 for `factory.number`). 


```{r 5M2}

# Create data set
N <- 1000                             
rho <- 0.5                         
tree.number <- rnorm(N)                     
factory.number <- rnorm(N, rho*tree.number, sqrt(1-rho^2))
pm.air <- rnorm(N, tree.number - factory.number)        
d <- data.frame(pm.air, tree.number, factory.number)  

# Air quality vs. trees
m.at <- lm(pm.air ~ 1 + tree.number, data = d)
precis(m.at)
d1 <- ggplot(d, aes(x = tree.number, y = pm.air)) +
  geom_point(color = col.alpha("green3", 0.2), size = 2) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", fullrange = T,
              color  = "green4", size = 1/2, 
              fill   = "green", alpha = 1/3) +
  labs(x = "Trees per hectare (x100)", y = "Particulate matter (ug/m^3)") +
  theme_bw() 

# Air quality vs. factory
m.af <- lm(pm.air ~ 1 + factory.number, data = d)
precis(m.af)
d2 <- ggplot(d, aes(x = factory.number, y = pm.air)) +
  geom_point(color = col.alpha("red3", 0.2), size = 2) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", fullrange = T,
              color  = "red4", size = 1/2, 
              fill   = "red", alpha = 1/3) +
  labs(x = "Number of factories", y = "Particulate matter (ug/m^3)") +
  theme_bw() 
 grid.arrange(d1, d2, ncol = 2)
 
 
 # Air quality vs. number of trees and number of factories
 m.atf <- lm(pm.air ~ 1 + tree.number + factory.number, data = d)
 precis(m.atf)
 pairs(~ pm.air + tree.number + factory.number, data = d, col = col.alpha("skyblue", 0.4))

```

<br>

> 5M3. It is sometimes observed that the best predictor of fire risk is the presence of firefighters— States and localities with many firefighters also have more fires. Presumably firefighters do not cause fires. Nevertheless, this is not a spurious correlation. Instead fires cause firefighters. Consider the same reversal of causal inference in the context of the divorce and marriage data. How might a high divorce rate cause a higher marriage rate? Can you think of a way to evaluate this relationship, using multiple regression?

```{r 5M3}
# load data
data("WaffleDivorce")
d <- WaffleDivorce

## Try fitting divorce rate vs. marriage.rate first
# Standardize the variable
d$Divorce.s <- (d$Divorce - mean(d$Divorce))/ sd(d$Divorce)

# fit model
m.5m3.a <- lm(Marriage ~ 1 + Divorce.s, data = d)
precis(m.5m3.a)

```

So, with every sd increase in divorces, there is 1.42 increase in marriage cases. Since this is not a spurious relationship, a logical explanation of this phenomenon would be people remarry after divorce. In order to analyse this using multiple regression, the marriage data needs to be split into first marriage, second marriage, etc (Divorce rate may not correlate with first marriages but with remarriages). But then, the marriage and divorce data are for the year 2009 only. How likely for the couples to remarry within the same year of divorce? It is possible, but it's not typically considered a norm. So, that means within the year 2009, it is possible that increased divorce cases did not result in more marriages&mdash; more people were actually getting married for the first time. To assume a causal inference between divorce and marriage rate, we need to analyse data for more years (longitudinal data). Even then, the term causal inference sounds quite easy for divorce and remarriage rate. Of course, people can only remarry after divorce, but does divorce cause people to remarry? This is different from the assumption *"fire causes firefighters."* Fire can cause an increased in firefighters because firefighters are necessary to put out the fire (a danger). But, is it necessary for people to remarry after divorce? Is being a divorcee a social disadvantage that people must remarry (is remarriage an inevitable consequence of getting divorced)? 

<br>

> 5M4. In the divorce data, States with high numbers of Mormons (members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, LDS) have much lower divorce rates than the regression models expected. Find a list of LDS population by State and use those numbers as a predictor variable, predicting divorce rate using marriage rate, median age at marriage, and percent LDS population (possibly standardized). You may want to consider transformations of the raw percent LDS variable.

```{r 5M4}

# I don't know which states have Mormons, so I copy the data from answer sheet
data(WaffleDivorce)
d <- WaffleDivorce
d$pct_LDS <- c(0.75, 4.53, 6.18, 1, 2.01, 2.82, 0.43, 0.55, 0.38,
  0.75, 0.82, 5.18, 26.35, 0.44, 0.66, 0.87, 1.25, 0.77, 0.64, 0.81,
  0.72, 0.39, 0.44, 0.58, 0.72, 1.14, 4.78, 1.29, 0.61, 0.37, 3.34,
  0.41, 0.82, 1.48, 0.52, 1.2, 3.85, 0.4, 0.37, 0.83, 1.27, 0.75,
  1.21, 67.97, 0.74, 1.13, 3.99, 0.92, 0.44, 11.5 )

# Standardize the variables
d$pct_LDS.s <- (d$pct_LDS - mean(d$pct_LDS))/ sd(d$pct_LDS)
d$Marriage.s <- (d$Marriage - mean(d$Marriage))/ sd(d$Marriage)
d$MedianAgeMarriage.s <- (d$MedianAgeMarriage - mean(d$MedianAgeMarriage))/ sd(d$MedianAgeMarriage)

# Predict divorce rate using marriage rate, median age at marriage, and percent LDS population
m.5m4.s <- lm(d$Divorce ~ 1 + d$Marriage.s + d$MedianAgeMarriage.s + d$pct_LDS.s )

precis(m.5m4.s)

# Each standard deviation increase in percent of Mormons, the divorce rate will be reduced by 
# 0.62 divorces per 1000 adults.  

```

<br>

> 5M5. One way to reason through multiple causation hypotheses is to imagine detailed mechanisms through which predictor variables may influence outcomes. For example, it is sometimes argued that the price of gasoline (predictor variable) is positively associated with lower obesity rates (outcome variable). However, there are at least two important mechanisms by which the price of gas could reduce obesity. First, it could lead to less driving and therefore more exercise. Second, it could lead to less driving, which leads to less eating out, which leads to less consumption of huge restaurant meals. Can you outline one or more multiple regressions that address these two mechanisms? Assume you can have any predictor data you need.

<span style="color:navy"><span style="text-decoration:underline">***First mechanism***</span>

Higher gasoline price leads to people using public transportation more and less driving. That reduces traffic congestion, leading to lower air pollution which can cause people to go out more and exercise during free time (fresh air and more spaces). Those who don't use public transportation may walk or ride bicycle, resulting in more exercise. This can result in reduce obesity. The assumptions are:

- Gasoline price (G) increases usage of public transportation (T).

- Gasoline price (G) reduces driving (D).

- T and D reduces traffic congestion (C).

- C increases air quality (F) and space (S).

- F, S, T, and D increases exercise (E).

- E reduces obesity (O). 

<br>

<span style="color:navy"><span style="text-decoration:underline">***Second mechanism***</span>

High gasoline price leads to less driving, which leads to less eating out. Also, high gasoline price increases food food prices (higher cost of food production and transportation), leading to less eating out. 

- D reduces eating out at restaurants (R).

- G increases food prices (P).

- P reduces R.

- R reduces O. 

***Here I included many predictor variables I could think of at the moment. Using all predictors to fit multiple regressions is a bad idea. So, predictor variables need to be thoroughly checked and weeded out before building the regression model.***

<br>

### Hard

> 5H1. Fit two bivariate Gaussian regressions, using map: (1) body weight as a linear function of territory size (area), and (2) body weight as a linear function of groupsize. Plot the results of these regressions, displaying the MAP regression line and the 95% interval of the mean. Is either variable important for predicting fox body weight?

```{r 5H1}

# Load data
data(foxes)
d <- foxes
str(d)
par(mfrow = c(1,2))

#  body weight as a linear function of territory size (area)
m.ts <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    weight ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + bT * area,
    a ~ dnorm(0, 100),
    bT ~ dnorm(0, 1),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
  ), 
  data = d
)

precis(m.ts)

a.seq <- seq(from = 0, to = 7, by = 0.1)
mu <- link(m.ts, data = data.frame(area = a.seq))
mu.mean <- apply(mu, 2 , mean)
mu.PI <- apply(mu, 2, PI, prob = 0.95)
plot(weight ~ area, col = col.alpha("brown3", alpha = 0.5), data = d, pch = 19)
lines(a.seq, mu.mean, col = "brown4")
shade(mu.PI, a.seq, col = col.alpha("brown", alpha = 0.4))

# body weight as a linear function of groupsize
m.gs <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    weight ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + bG * groupsize,
    a ~ dnorm(0, 100),
    bG ~ dnorm(0, 1),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
  ),
  data = d
)

precis(m.gs)

g.seq <- seq(from = 0, to = 10, by = 0.1)
mu <- link(m.gs, data = data.frame(groupsize = g.seq))
mu.mean <- apply(mu, 2, mean)
mu.PI <- apply(mu, 2, PI, prob = 0.95)
plot(weight ~ groupsize, col = col.alpha("slateblue3", alpha = 0.5), data = d, pch = 19)
lines(g.seq, mu.mean, col = "slateblue4")
shade(mu.PI, g.seq, col = col.alpha("slateblue", alpha = 0.4))

# The regression line between area and body weight is almost linear and data points are
# quite scattered in the plot, showing there's almost no correlation between area and body weight. 
# The effect of group size on body weight seems a bit larger than that of area, but does not show 
# strong association. Both variables are not a strong predictor of the outcome, but group size seems 
# more promising than area. 

```

<br>

> 5H2. Now fit a multiple linear regression with weight as the outcome and both area and groupsize as predictor variables. Plot the predictions of the model for each predictor, holding the other predictor constant at its mean. What does this model say about the importance of each variable? Why do you get different results than you got in the exercise just above?

```{r 5H2}

# Load data
data("foxes")
d <- foxes

# Fit model
m.ag <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    weight ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + bT * area + bG * groupsize,
    a ~ dnorm(0, 100),
    bT ~ dnorm(0, 1),
    bG ~ dnorm(0, 1),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
  ),
  data = d
)

precis(m.ag)

par(mfrow = c(1,2))

## When group size is constant
a.seq <- seq(from = 0, to = 7, by = 0.1)
g.avg <- mean(d$groupsize)
pred.area <- data.frame(
  area = a.seq,
  groupsize = g.avg
)

mu <- link(m.ag, data = pred.area)
mu.mean <- apply(mu, 2, mean)
mu.PI <- apply(mu, 2, PI, prob = 0.95)

# Plot data
plot(weight ~ area, col = col.alpha("brown3", alpha = 0.5), data = d, pch = 19)
lines(a.seq, mu.mean, col = "brown4")
shade(mu.PI, a.seq, col = col.alpha("brown", alpha = 0.4))
mtext("Group size is constant at mean value", col = "brown")

## When area is held constant
g.seq <- seq(from = 0, to = 10, by = 0.1)
a.avg <- mean(d$area)
pred.group <- data.frame(
  groupsize = g.seq,
  area = a.avg
)

mu <- link(m.ag, data = pred.group)
mu.mean <- apply(mu, 2, mean)
mu.PI <- apply(mu, 2, PI, prob = 0.95)

# Plot the data
plot(weight ~ groupsize, col = col.alpha("slateblue3", alpha = 0.5), data = d, pch = 19)
lines(g.seq, mu.mean, col = "slateblue4")
shade(mu.PI, g.seq, col = col.alpha("slateblue", alpha = 0.4))
mtext("Area is constant at mean value", col = "slateblue")

# The correlations become a lot stronger for both predictors. This is an example of 
# masked relationship where predictors are correlated with one another but have opposite 
# correlation with the outcome variable. Both variables are strong predictors of outcome 
# in this model, but the raw (observed) data points don't seem to fit well with the model- 
# maybe because we hold a predictor constant in the model where this is impossible in raw 
# observed data. 

```

<br>

> 5H3. Finally, consider the avgfood variable. Fit two more multiple regressions: (1) body weight as an additive function of avgfood and groupsize, and (2) body weight as an additive function of all three variables, avgfood and groupsize and area. Compare the results of these models to the previous models you’ve fit, in the first two exercises. (a) Is avgfood or area a better predictor of body weight? If you had to choose one or the other to include in a model, which would it be? Support your assessment with any tables or plots you choose. (b) When both avgfood or area are in the same model, their effects are reduced (closer to zero) and their standard errors are larger than when they are included in separate models. Can you explain this result?

```{r 5H3}

# Load data
data(foxes)
d <- foxes

# body weight as an additive function of avgfood and groupsize
m.fg <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    weight ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + bF * avgfood + bG * groupsize,
    a ~ dnorm(0, 100),
    bF ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    bG ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
  ),
  data = d
)

precis(m.fg)

pairs(~ weight + avgfood + groupsize, data = d, col = "brown3")

# body weight as an additive function of avgfood and groupsize and area
m.fga <- rethinking::map(
  alist(
    weight ~ dnorm(mu, sigma),
    mu <- a + bF * avgfood + bG * groupsize + bT * area,
    a ~ dnorm(0, 100),
    bG ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    bF ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    bT ~ dnorm(0, 10),
    sigma ~ dunif(0, 10)
  ),
  data = d
)

precis(m.fga)

pairs(~ weight + avgfood + groupsize + area, data = d, col = "slateblue3")

# (a) Average food because a bit higher increase in weight per unit of average food increase,
# as seen in the table (model m.fga). 

# (b) It could be because average food and area are highly correlated with each other.

```

<br>

# Chapter 6: Overfitting, Regularization, and Information Criteria

<br>

<span style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Two fundamental kinds of statistical error:**</span></span>

(1) ***Overfitting:*** leads to poor prediction by learning too much from the data

(2) ***Underfitting:*** leads to poor prediction by learning too little from the data

<br>

<span style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Two approaches to address the errors:**</span></span>

(1) ***Regularizing prior:*** tells the model not to get too excited by the data (penalized likelihood)

(2) ***Information criteria:*** scoring device to model the prediction task and estimate predictive accuracy for some purpose 

*Both can be&mdash; maybe should be&mdash; used in combination.*

<br>

## The problem with parameters

There are two principle concerns with just adding variables. 

The first is that adding parameters&mdash; making the model more complex&mdash; nearly always improves the fit of a model to the data. For example, like other measures of fit to sample, *R^2^* increases as more predictor variables are added. This is true even when the variables added to a model are just random numbers, with no relation to the outcome. So it’s no good to choose among models using only fit to the data.

Second, while more complex models fit the data better, they often predict new data worse. Models that have many parameters tend to overfit more than do simpler models. This means that a complex model will be very sensitive to the exact sample used to fit it, leading to potentially large mistakes when future data is not exactly like the past data. But simple models, with too few parameters, tend instead to underfit, systematically over-predicting or under-predicting the data, regardless of how well future data resemble past data. So we can’t always favor either simple models or complex models.

<br>

## More parameters always improve fit

Overfitting occurs when a model learns too much from the sample. This is a general phenomenon: If you adopt a model family with enough parameters, you can fit the data exactly. But such a model will make rather absurd predictions for yet-to-be-observed cases.

```{r 6.1, fig.height=10}

## Create data set for average brain volumes and body masses for seven hominin species
sppnames <- c( "afarensis","africanus","habilis","boisei",
    "rudolfensis","ergaster","sapiens")

brainvolcc <- c( 438 , 452 , 612, 521, 752, 871, 1350 )

masskg <- c( 37.0 , 35.5 , 34.5 , 41.5 , 55.5 , 61.0 , 53.5 )

d <- data.frame( species=sppnames , brain=brainvolcc , mass=masskg )

## Fit model that relates brain size to body size 
m6.1 <- lm( brain ~ mass , data=d )
summary(m6.1)

# Calculate R^2
1 - var(resid(m6.1))/var(d$brain)
# Same number as 'multipled R-squared' from summary(m6.1)

## Create other models to compare to the fit of m6.1
# Second-degree polynomial (parabola) that relates body size to brain size
m6.2 <- lm( brain ~ mass + I(mass^2) , data=d )

# Third-degree polynomial
m6.3 <- lm( brain ~ mass + I(mass^2) + I(mass^3) , data=d )

# Fourth-degree polynomial
m6.4 <- lm( brain ~ mass + I(mass^2) + I(mass^3) + I(mass^4) ,
    data=d )

# Fifth-degree polynomial
m6.5 <- lm( brain ~ mass + I(mass^2) + I(mass^3) + I(mass^4) +
    I(mass^5) , data=d )

# Sixth-degree polynomial
m6.6 <- lm( brain ~ mass + I(mass^2) + I(mass^3) + I(mass^4) +
    I(mass^5) + I(mass^6) , data=d )

## Plot the data

# Linear model
 d1 <- ggplot(d, aes(x = masskg, y = brainvolcc)) +
  geom_point(color = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.8), size = 2, shape = 21, stroke = 1) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", fullrange = T,
               level = 0.89, 
              color  = "black", size = 1/2, 
              fill   = "grey", alpha = 1/3,
              formula = y ~ x) +
   coord_cartesian(ylim = c(300, 1500)) +
    scale_x_continuous(limits = c(33, 62), expand = c(0, 0)) +
  labs(x = "body mass (kg)", y = "brain volume (cc)", title = "R^2 = 0.49") +
  theme_bw() +
    theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) +
   theme(plot.title = element_text(size=11)) +
   theme(panel.grid.major = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor = element_blank())
 
# Second-degree polynomial
d2 <- ggplot(d, aes(x = masskg, y = brainvolcc)) +
  geom_point(color = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.8), size = 2, shape = 21,
             stroke = 1) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", fullrange = T,
               level = 0.89, 
              color  = "black", size = 1/2, 
              fill   = "grey", alpha = 1/3,
              formula = y ~ poly(x, 2)) +
  coord_cartesian(ylim = c(300, 1500)) +
   scale_x_continuous(limits = c(33, 62), expand = c(0, 0)) +
  labs(x = "body mass (kg)", y = "brain volume (cc)", title = "R^2 = 0.54") +
  theme_bw() +
   theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size=11)) +
  theme(panel.grid.major = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor = element_blank())
 
# Third-degree polynomial
 d3 <- ggplot(d, aes(x = masskg, y = brainvolcc)) +
   geom_point(color = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.8), size = 2, shape = 21, 
              stroke = 1) +
   geom_smooth(method = "lm", fullrange = T,
                level = 0.89, 
               color = "black", size = 1/2,
               fill = "grey", alpha = 1/3,
               formula = y ~ poly(x, 3)) +
   coord_cartesian(ylim = c(300, 1500)) +
    scale_x_continuous(limits = c(33, 62), expand = c(0, 0)) +
   labs(x = "body mass (kg)", y = "brain volume (cc)", title = "R^2 = 0.68") +
   theme_bw() +
    theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) +
   theme(plot.title = element_text(size=11)) +
   theme(panel.grid.major = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor = element_blank())
 
 # Fourth-degree polynomial
 d4 <- ggplot(d, aes(x = masskg, y = brainvolcc)) +
   geom_point(color = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.8), size = 2, shape = 21,
              stroke = 1) +
   geom_smooth(method = "lm", fullrange = T,
                level = 0.89, 
               color = "black", size = 1/2,
               fill = "grey", alpha = 1/3,
               formula = y ~ poly(x, 4)) +
   coord_cartesian(ylim = c(300, 1500)) +
    scale_x_continuous(limits = c(33, 62), expand = c(0, 0)) +
   labs(x = "body mass (kg)", y = "brain volume (cc)", title = "R^2 = 0.81") +
   theme_bw() +
    theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) +
   theme(plot.title = element_text(size=11)) +
   theme(panel.grid.major = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor = element_blank())
 
# Fifth-degree polynomial
 d5 <- ggplot(d, aes(x = masskg, y = brainvolcc)) +
   geom_point(color = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.8), size = 2, shape = 21, 
              stroke = 1) +
   geom_smooth(method = "lm", fullrange = TRUE,
                level = 0.89, 
               color = "black", size = 1/2,
               fill = "grey", alpha = 1/3,
               formula = y ~ poly(x, 5)) +
   coord_cartesian(ylim = c(150, 1900)) +
    scale_x_continuous(limits = c(33, 62), expand = c(0, 0)) +
   labs(x = "body mass (kg)", y = "brain volume (cc)", title = "R^2 = 0.99") +
   theme_bw() +
    theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) +
   theme(plot.title = element_text(size=11)) +
   theme(panel.grid.major = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor = element_blank())
 
 # Sixth-degree polynomial
 d6 <- ggplot(d, aes(x = masskg, y = brainvolcc)) +
   geom_point(color = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.8), size = 2, shape = 21, 
              stroke = 1) +
   geom_smooth(method = "lm", fullrange = TRUE,
               level = 0.89, 
               color = "black", size = 1/2,
               fill = "grey", alpha = 1/3,
               formula = y ~ poly(x, 6)) +
   geom_hline(yintercept = 0, color = "black", linetype = 2) +
    coord_cartesian(ylim = c(-300, 1500)) +
    scale_x_continuous(limits = c(34, 62), expand = c(0, 0)) +
   labs(x = "body mass (kg)", y = "brain volume (cc)", title = "R^2 = 1.00") +
   theme_bw() +
    theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) +
   theme(plot.title = element_text(size=11)) +
   theme(panel.grid.major = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor = element_blank())
 
 grid.arrange(d1, d2, d3, d4, d5, d6, layout_matrix = matrix(c(1:6), 
                                                             ncol = 2, 
                                                             byrow = TRUE))
 
 # As the degree of the polynomial defining the mean increases, the fit always improves. 
 # However, you can see from looking at the paths of the predicted means that the 
 # higher-degree polynomials are increasingly absurd. 
 # The sixth-degree polynomial fit perfectly because it has enough parameters to assign
 # one to each point of data. The model’s equation for the mean has 7 parameters and there 
 # are 7 species to predict brain sizes for.
 
```

<br>

## Too few parameters hurts, too

The overfit polynomial models manage to fit the data extremely well, but they suffer for this within-sample accuracy by making nonsensical out-of-sample predictions. In contrast, underfitting produces models that are inaccurate both within and out of sample. They have learned too little, failing to recover regular features of the sample.

```{r 6.6}

# Load data 
sppnames <- c( "afarensis","africanus","habilis","boisei",
    "rudolfensis","ergaster","sapiens")
brainvolcc <- c( 438 , 452 , 612, 521, 752, 871, 1350 )
masskg <- c( 37.0 , 35.5 , 34.5 , 41.5 , 55.5 , 61.0 , 53.5 )
d <- data.frame( species=sppnames , brain=brainvolcc , mass=masskg )

# Consider a model of brain volume where mu = a (no predictor variable, just intercept a)
m6.7 <- lm( brain ~ 1 , data=d )

# Plot the data
ggplot(d, aes(x = masskg, y = brainvolcc)) +
  geom_point(color = col.alpha(rangi2, 0.8), size = 2, shape = 21, stroke = 1) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", fullrange = T,
               level = 0.89, 
              color  = "black", size = 1/2, 
              fill   = "grey", alpha = 1/3,
              formula = y ~ 1) +
   scale_x_continuous(limits = c(30, 65), expand = c(0, 0)) +
  labs(x = "body mass (kg)", y = "brain volume (cc)", title = "R^2 = 0") +
  theme_bw() +
    theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) +
   theme(plot.title = element_text(size=11)) +
   theme(panel.grid.major = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor = element_blank())

# An underfit model of hominin brain volume. This model ignores any association between 
# body mass and brain volume, producing a horizontal line of predictions. As a result, 
# the model fits badly and (presumably) predicts badly.

```

<br>

Another way to conceptualize an underfit model is to notice that it is insensitive to the sample. We could remove any one point from the sample and get pretty much the same regression line. In contrast, the most complex model, m6.6, is very sensitive to the sample. The predicted mean would change course a lot, if we removed any one point from the sample.

```{r f6.5}
# Create seven sets of data by dropping a row each time
d1 <- droplevels(d[!d$species == "sapiens", ])
d2 <- droplevels(d[!d$species == "ergaster", ])
d3 <- droplevels(d[!d$species == "rudolfensis", ])
d4 <- droplevels(d[!d$species == "boisei", ])
d5 <- droplevels(d[!d$species == "habilis", ])
d6 <- droplevels(d[!d$species == "africanus", ])
d7 <- droplevels(d[!d$species == "afarenis", ])


## Fit the models (First- degree polynomials: Underfit example) 
m1 <- lm(brain ~ mass, data = d1)
m2 <- lm(brain ~ mass, data = d2)
m3 <- lm(brain ~ mass, data = d3)
m4 <- lm(brain ~ mass, data = d4)
m5 <- lm(brain ~ mass, data = d5)
m6 <- lm(brain ~ mass, data = d6)
m7 <- lm(brain ~ mass, data = d7)

par(mfrow = c(1,2))
# Plot the data
plot(d$mass, d$brain,
      xlim = range(d$mass), ylim = range(d$brain), pch = 1,
     col = "blue", xlab = "body mass (kg)", ylab = "brain volume (cc)",
     main = "My plot")
abline(m1)
abline(m2)
abline(m3)
abline(m4)
abline(m5)
abline(m6)
abline(m7)

plot( brain ~ mass , d , col="slateblue" , main = "Given example")
for ( i in 1:nrow(d) ) {
    d.new <- d[ -i , ]
    m0 <- lm( brain ~ mass, d.new )
    abline( m0 , col=col.alpha("black",0.5) )
}

```


```{r f6.5a}

### Use codes from "ajkurz"
# Create base plot
p <-
  d %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mass, y = brain)) +
  geom_point(color = "slateblue", size = 3, shape = 21)  +
  scale_x_continuous("body mass (kg)", limits = c(33, 62), expand = c(0, 0)) +
  coord_cartesian(ylim = c(300, 1500)) +
  ylab("brain volume (cc)") +
  ggtitle("(a)") +
  theme_bw() +
  theme(panel.grid.major = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

# If drop second row
d %>%
  filter(row_number() != 2)
# We can then extend that logic into a custom function, make_lines(), that will drop a 
# row from d, fit the simple model brain ~ mass, and then use base R predict() to return 
# the model-implied trajectory over new data values.

## Fit the models (First- degree polynomials: Underfit example) 
# because these lines are straight, we only need new data over two points of `mass`
nd <- tibble(mass = c(30, 70))

make_lines <- function(row){
  my_fit <-
    d %>%
    filter(row_number() != row) %>% 
    lm(formula = brain ~ mass)

  predict(my_fit, nd) %>% 
    as_tibble() %>% 
    rename(brain = value) %>% 
    bind_cols(nd)
}

# Here we’ll make a tibble, lines, which will specify rows 1 through 7 in the row column.
# We’ll then feed those row numbers into our custom make_lines() function, which will return 
# the predicted values and their corresponding mass values, per model.
(
  lines <-
  tibble(row = 1:7) %>% 
  mutate(p = map(row, make_lines)) %>% 
  unnest(p)
  )

# Plot the data
p1 <- p + 
  scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0, 0)) +
  geom_line(data = lines, 
            aes(x = mass, y = brain, group = row),
            color = "black", alpha = 1/2, size = 1/2)

## Fit the models (Sixth-order polynomials: Overfit example)
p <-
  d %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mass, y = brain)) +
  geom_point(color = "slateblue", size = 3, shape = 21)  +
  scale_x_continuous("body mass (kg)", limits = c(33, 62), expand = c(0, 0)) +
  coord_cartesian(ylim = c(300, 1500)) +
  ylab("brain volume (cc)") +
  ggtitle("(b)") +
```
