- Sometimes model fitting has a hard time with uncentered variables. Centering (and possibly also standardizing) the data before fitting the model can help you achieve a faster and more reliable set of estimates.

<br>

### The data

The data in this example are sizes of blooms from beds of tulips grown in greenhouses, under different soil and light conditions.

```{r 7.18}

# Load the data
data(tulips)
d <- tulips
str(d)

```

The `blooms` column will be our outcome. The `water` and `shade` columns will be our predictor variables. Independent effects of sunlight (`shade`) and `water` will produce bigger blooms. We are also interested in the interaction between these two variables. How will the `water` help in the absence of light, or will sunlight helps the blooms in the absence of water? One way to model such an interdependency is to use an interaction effect.

<br>

### The un-centered models

Example focusing on just two models: 

(1) the model with both `water` and `shade` but no interaction 

(2) the model with both main effects and the interaction of `water` with `shade`

<br>

The main effect likelihood is:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}B_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_W W_i + \beta_S S_i\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

And the full interaction likelihood is:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}B_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_W W_i + \beta_S S_i + \beta_{WS} W_i S_i\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

```
B_i    = the value of bloom on row i 

W_i    = the value of water

S_i    = the value of shade.

```

```{r 7.19}

set.seed(717)

m7.6 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        blooms ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bW*water + bS*shade ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bW ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bS ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 100 ) ),
    data=d )

m7.7 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        blooms ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bW*water + bS*shade + bWS*water*shade ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bW ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bS ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bWS ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 100 )
), data=d )
# The model fitting engine, R’s optim, searched for a very long time. It searched so long 
# that it reached the time limit, the “maximum iterations.” As a result, the estimates are 
# unreliable and should not be used, unless you are sure they are okay.

```

<br>

<span style="color:gray">***Fix the maximum iterations problem.***</span>

```{r 7.19a}
set.seed(719)
# Use  Nelder-Mead method of optimization
m7.6 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        blooms ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bW*water + bS*shade ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bW ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bS ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 100 ) ),
    data=d ,
    method="Nelder-Mead" ,
    control=list(maxit=1e4) )

m7.7 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        blooms ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bW*water + bS*shade + bWS*water*shade ,
        a ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bW ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bS ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bWS ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 100 )
),
data=d , method="Nelder-Mead" , control=list(maxit=1e4) )

# Use coeftab function to check the estimates
coeftab(m7.6,m7.7)
# In main-effects-only model (m7.6), for every additional level of soil moisture, 
# blooms increase by 76, on average. For every addition unit of shade, 
# blooms decrease by 42, on average. 

# In interaction model (m7.7), both main effects are positive, but the new interaction
# posterior mean is negative.

# WAIC values assure that the interaction model is indeed a much better model
compare( m7.6 , m7.7 )

```

<br>

### Center and re-estimate

To *center* a variable means to create a new variable that contains the same information as the original, but has a new mean of zero. Centering can help with two things in this analysis:

- fix our previous problem with maximum iterations

- make the estimates easier to interpret

```{r 7.23}

# Make centered versions of shade and water by subtracting the mean of the original from each value
d$shade.c <- d$shade - mean(d$shade)
d$water.c <- d$water - mean(d$water)

# Re-estimate m7.6 and m7.7 using centered variables
m7.8 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        blooms ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bW*water.c + bS*shade.c ,
        a ~ dnorm( 130 , 100 ) ,
        bW ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bS ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 100 )
),
data=d , start=list(a=mean(d$blooms),bW=0,bS=0,sigma=sd(d$blooms)) )

m7.9 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        blooms ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bW*water.c + bS*shade.c + bWS*water.c*shade.c ,
        a ~ dnorm( 130 , 100 ) ,
        bW ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bS ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        bWS ~ dnorm( 0 , 100 ) ,
        sigma ~ dunif( 0 , 100 )
),
data=d , start=list(a=mean(d$blooms),bW=0,bS=0,bWS=0,sigma=sd(d$blooms)) )


# Check estimates
coeftab(m7.8,m7.9)
# Now when we compare the posterior means across the two models, the main effects are the same. 
# Unlike before, the direction of the association for shade has not changed. More water appears 
# to directly increase blooms, while more shade directly decreases them. Meanwhile, the 
# interaction posterior mean has remained the same as it was in the non-centered model.
## Centering has these effects because: Estimation worked better, Estimates changed less across models.

```

<br>

#### Estimation worked better

Estimation failed with the un-centered predictor variables, because there was a long way to go from the `start` values you provided to map and the `MAP` values it was seeking. When the predictors are centered, the MAP value for <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\alpha}" title="" /> is just the empirical mean for the outcome. That is also the `start` value given to `map`. With un-centered predictors, the MAP value for <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\alpha}" title="" /> lies a long way from the empirical mean. Hence, the long search that failed.

<br>

#### Estimates changed less across models

In the un-centered models, the interaction effect is applied to every case, and so none of the parameters in <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\mu}" title="" /> makes sense alone. This is because neither of the predictors in those models, `shade` and `water`, are ever zero. As a result the interaction parameter always factors into generating a prediction. Consider for example a tulip at the average moisture and shade levels, 2 in each case. The expected blooms for such a tulip is:

![\large ](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\boldsymbol{\mu_i|_{S_i=2, W_i=2} = \alpha + \beta_W(2) + \beta_S (2) + \beta_{WS}(2 \times 2)})

<br>

```{r 7.25}

# Plugging in the MAP values for the un-centered interaction model, m7.7
k <- coef(m7.7)
k[1] + k[2]*2 + k[3]*2 + k[4]*2*2

# Same prediction from the centered interaction model, m7.9,
# also using the mean values of both predictors
k <- coef(m7.9)
k[1] + k[2]*0 + k[3]*0 + k[4]*0*0
precis(m7.9)
# The estimate a,α, is the expected value of blooms when both water and shade are at 
# their average values. Their average values are both zero (0), because they were centered 
# before fitting the model.

# The estimate bW, βW, is the expected change in blooms when water increases by one unit 
# and shade is at its average value (of zero). This parameter does not tell you the expected 
# rate of change for any other value of shade. This estimate suggests that when shade is at 
# its average value, increasing water is highly beneficial to blooms.

# The estimate bS, βS, is the expected change in blooms when shade increases by one unit and 
# water is at its average value (of zero). This parameter does not tell you the expected rate 
# of change for any other value of water. This estimate suggests that when water is at its 
# average value, increasing shade is highly detrimental to blooms.

# The estimate bWS, βWS, is the interaction effect. Like all linear interactions, it can be 
# explained in more than one way. First, the estimate tells us the expected change in the 
# influence of water on blooms when increasing shade by one unit. Second, it tells us the 
# expected change in the influence of shade on blooms when increasing water by one unit.

```

<br>

### Plotting implied predictions

There were no interactions in the models in previous chapters. As a result, when plotting model predictions as a function of any one predictor, you could hold the other predictors constant at any value you liked. So the choice of which values to set the un-viewed predictor variables to hardly mattered.

Once there are interactions in a model, the effect of changing a predictor depends upon the values of the other predictors. Maybe the simplest way to go about plotting such interdependency is to make a frame of multiple bivariate plots. In each plot, you choose different values for the un-viewed variables. Then by comparing the plots to one another, you can see how big of a difference the changes make.

```{r 7.28, fig.width=8, fig.height=6}

# make a plot window with three panels in a single row
par(mfrow=c(2,3), mar = c(4, 4, 4, 4)) # 2 row, 3 columns

## Without interaction
# loop over values of water.c and plot predictions
shade.seq <- -1:1
for ( w in -1:1 ) {
    dt <- d[d$water.c==w,]
    plot( blooms ~ shade.c , data=dt , col=rangi2 ,
        main=paste("water.c =",w) , xaxp=c(-1,1,2) , ylim=c(0,362) ,
        xlab="shade (centered)" )
    mu <- link( m7.8 , data=data.frame(water.c=w,shade.c=shade.seq) )
    mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
    mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI , prob=0.97 )
    lines( shade.seq , mu.mean )
    lines( shade.seq , mu.PI[1,] , lty=2 )
    lines( shade.seq , mu.PI[2,] , lty=2 )
}

## With interaction
# loop over values of water.c and plot predictions
shade.seq <- -1:1
for ( w in -1:1 ) {
    dt <- d[d$water.c==w,]
    plot( blooms ~ shade.c , data=dt , col=rangi2 ,
        main=paste("water.c =",w) , xaxp=c(-1,1,2) , ylim=c(0,362) ,
        xlab="shade (centered)" )
    mu <- link( m7.9 , data=data.frame(water.c=w,shade.c=shade.seq) )
    mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
    mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI , prob=0.97 )
    lines( shade.seq , mu.mean )
    lines( shade.seq , mu.PI[1,] , lty=2 )
    lines( shade.seq , mu.PI[2,] , lty=2 )
}

# Triptych plot of predicted blooms across water treatments, without (top row) and 
# with (bottom row) an interaction effect. Blue points in each plot are data- individual 
# cases that match the water value displayed at the top of each plot.
# The solid line is the posterior mean and the dashed lines give 97% interval of the mean.

# Top row: Without the interaction, model m7.8. Each of the three plots of blooms against 
# shade level is for a different water level. The slope of the regression line in each case 
# is exactly the same, because there is no interaction in this model. 

# Bottom row: With the interaction, model m7.9. Now the slope of blooms against shade has 
# a different value in each plot.At low water levels, shade can’t have much of an effect, 
# because the tulips don’t have enough water to produce blooms anyway. At higher water levels, 
# shade can matter more, because the tulips have enough water to produce some blooms. 
# At very high water levels, water is no longer limiting the blooms very much, and so shade 
# can have a much more dramatic impact on the outcome.

```

<br>

```{r 7.28a, fig.width=8, fig.height=6}

## Water on the horizontal axes and shade level varied from left to right

par(mfrow=c(2,3), mar = c(4, 4, 4, 4))

## Without interaction
# loop over values of shade.c and plot predictions
water.seq <- -1:1
for ( s in -1:1 ) {
    dt <- d[d$shade.c==s,]
    plot( blooms ~ water.c , data=dt , col=rangi2 ,
        main=paste("shade.c =",s) , xaxp=c(-1,1,2) , ylim=c(0,362) ,
        xlab="water (centered)" )
    mu <- link( m7.8 , data=data.frame(shade.c=s,water.c=water.seq) )
    mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
    mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI , prob=0.97 )
    lines( water.seq , mu.mean )
    lines( water.seq , mu.PI[1,] , lty=2 )
    lines( water.seq , mu.PI[2,] , lty=2 )
}

## With interaction
# loop over values of shade.c and plot predictions
water.seq <- -1:1
for ( s in -1:1 ) {
    dt <- d[d$shade.c==s,]
    plot( blooms ~ water.c , data=dt , col=rangi2 ,
        main=paste("shade.c =",s) , xaxp=c(-1,1,2) , ylim=c(0,362) ,
        xlab="water (centered)" )
    mu <- link( m7.9 , data=data.frame(shade.c=s,water.c=water.seq) )
    mu.mean <- apply( mu , 2 , mean )
    mu.PI <- apply( mu , 2 , PI , prob=0.97 )
    lines( water.seq , mu.mean )
    lines( water.seq , mu.PI[1,] , lty=2 )
    lines( water.seq , mu.PI[2,] , lty=2 )
}
# If there isn’t enough light, then more water hardly helps.

```

<br>

## Interactions in design formulas

To specify interaction models using design formulas, like those used by `lm` and other automated model fitting functions, you just strip out the parameters from the linear model.

For example, here’s a model with an interaction between *x* and *z*:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}y_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_x x_i + \beta_z z_i + \beta_{xz} x_i z_i\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

```{r 7.29}

# As a design formula, this is:
m7.x <- lm( y ~ x + z + x*z , data=d )

# You can also omit the pure x and z terms, the main effects, and still get the same model.
m7.x <- lm( y ~ x*z , data=d )

```

<br>

If you do not want the main effects in the model, you must explicitly subtract them from the formula. For example, here’s a model with an interaction, but without one of the main effects (when you know a priori that there is no direct effect of *z* on the outcome, when <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\beta_z}" title="" /> = 0 by assumption):

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}y_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_x x_i + \beta_{xz} x_i z_i\\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>


```{r 7.31}

# As a design formula, this model is:
m7.x <- lm( y ~ x + x*z - z , data=d )

```

<br>

For higher-order interactions, just multiply more predictors together. The design formula always implies all of the lower-order interactions, even though you don’t explicitly state them. For example, this model has a three-way interaction between *x*, *z*, and *w*, as well as three two-way interactions and all three main effects:

<img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?\inline&space;\dpi{110}\boldsymbol{\begin{align*}y_i &\sim Normal(\mu_i, \sigma)\\\mu_i &= \alpha + \beta_x x_i + \beta_z z_i + \beta_w w_i + \beta_{xz} x_i z_i + \beta_{xw} x_i w_i + \beta_{zw} z_i w_i + \beta_{xzw} x_i z_i w_i \\\end{align*}" title="" />

<br>

```{r 7.32}

# create mock data set to solve "error:variable lengths differ (found for 'w')"
d <- data.frame(
  y = rnorm(40),
  x = rnorm(40),
  z = rnorm(40),
  w = rnorm(40)
) 

## In design formula:
m7.x <- lm( y ~ x*z*w , data=d )
# And you can explicitly subtract any lower-order interactions or main effects to 
# construct a reduced model.

## Expand the design formula to see how it works
# Expand a three-way interaction into a full set of terms:
x <- z <- w <- 1 # any number would do here
colnames( model.matrix(~x*z*w) )
# That function takes the design formula, absent the outcome variable, and expands it 
# into a full set of variables for a linear model. This expanded set is the model matrix. 
# ":" symbols stand for multiplication.

```

<br>

## Practice










<br>

# Chapter 8: Markov Chain Monte Carlo

***Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) estimation*** is the estimation of posterior probability distributions using a stochastic process. It has the ability to directly estimate models, such as the generalized linear and multilevel models, which routinely produce non-Gaussian posterior distributions. 

<br>

## Good King Markov and his island kingdom

King Markov was a benevolent autocrat of an island kingdom,a circular archipelago, with 10 islands. Each island was neighbored by two others, and the entire archipelago formed a ring. The islands were of different sizes, and so had different sized populations living on them. The second island was about twice as populous as the first, the third about three times as populous as the first, and so on, up to the largest island, which was 10 times as populous as the smallest.

The king should visit each island in proportion to its population size, visiting the largest island 10 times as often as the smallest, for example. Also, since the archipelago was a ring, the King insisted that he only move among adjacent islands, to minimize time spent on the water. 

The king’s advisor, a Mr Metropolis, engineered a clever solution to these demands. We’ll call this solution the ***Metropolis algorithm***. Here's how it works.

(1) Wherever the King is, each week he decides between staying put for another week or moving to one of the two adjacent islands. To decide his next move, he flips a coin.

(2) If the coin turns up heads, the King considers moving to the adjacent island clockwise around the archipelago. If the coin turns up tails, he considers instead moving counterclockwise. Call the island the coin nominates the *proposal* island.

(3) Now, to see whether or not he moves to the proposal island, King Markov counts out a number of seashells equal to the relative population size of the proposal island. So for example, if the proposal island is number 9, then he counts out 9 seashells. Then he also counts out a number of stones equal to the relative population of the current island. So for example, if the current island is number 10, then King Markov ends up holding 10 stones, in addition to the 9 seashells.

(4) When there are more seashells than stones, King Markov always moves to the proposal island. But if there are fewer shells than stones, he discards a number of stones equal to the number of shells. So for example, if there are 4 shells and 6 stones, he ends up with 4 shells and 6 − 4 = 2 stones. Then he places the shells and the remaining stones in a bag. He reaches in and randomly pulls out one object. If it is a shell, he moves to the proposal island. Otherwise, he stays put another week. As a result, the probability that he moves is equal to the number of shells divided by the original number of stones.

```{r 8.1, fig.height=6, fig.width=10}

## Simulate King Markov’s journey (Use akjurz's codes)

set.seed(8)

num_weeks <- 1e5
positions <- rep(0, num_weeks)
current   <- 10
for (i in 1:num_weeks) {
  # record current position
  positions[i] <- current
  # flip coin to generate proposal
  proposal <- current + sample(c(-1, 1), size = 1)
  # now make sure he loops around the archipelago
  if (proposal < 1) proposal <- 10
  if (proposal > 10) proposal <- 1
  # move?
  prob_move <- proposal / current
  current   <- ifelse(runif(1) < prob_move, proposal, current)
}

d1 <-tibble(week   = 1:1e5,
       island = positions) %>%

  ggplot(aes(x = week, y = island)) +
  geom_point(shape = 1) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(from = 0, to = 100, by = 20)) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(from = 0, to = 10, by = 2)) +
 coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100),
                  ylim = c(1,10)) +
  labs(title    = "Behold: The Metropolis algorithm in action!",
       subtitle = "The dots show the king's path over the first 100 weeks.") +
  theme_ipsum()

d2 <-tibble(week   = 1:1e5,
       island = positions) %>%
  mutate(island = factor(island)) %>%

  ggplot(aes(x = island)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(title    = "Old Metropolis shines in the long run.",
       subtitle = "Sure enough, the time the king spent on each island was\nproportional to its population size.") +
  theme_ipsum()

grid.arrange(d1, d2, ncol = 2)
# Results of the king following the Metropolis algorithm. The left-hand plot shows 
# the king’s position (vertical axis) across first 100 weeks (horizontal axis). 
# In any particular week, it’s nearly impossible to say where the king will be. 

# The right-hand plot shows the long-run behavior of the algorithm, as the time spent on 
# each island turns out to be proportional to its population size.

# The algorithm will still work in this way, even if we allow the king to be equally likely 
# to propose a move to any island from any island, not just among neighbors. The algorithm 
# would also work for any size archipelago, even if the king didn’t know how many islands 
# were in it. All he needs to know at any point in time is the population of the current 
# island and the population of the proposal island.

```

<br>

## Markov chain Monte Carlo

The goal of general **Metropolis Algorithm**, an example of Markov chain Monte Carlo, is to draw samples from an unknown and usually complex target distribution, like a posterior probability distribution.

- The “islands” in our objective are parameter values, and they need not be discrete, but can instead take on a continuous range of values as usual.

- The “population sizes” in our objective are the posterior probabilities at each parameter value.

- The “weeks” in our objective are samples taken from the joint posterior of the parameters in the model.

Provided the way we choose our proposed parameter values at each step is symmetric&mdash; so that there is an equal chance of proposing from A to B and from B to A&mdash; then the Metropolis algorithm will eventually give us a collection of samples from the joint posterior.

<br>

<spans style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Two of the most important in contemporary Bayesian inference**</span>

- Gibbs sampling

- Hamiltonian (aka Hybrid, aka HMC) Monte Carlo

<br>

### Gibbs sampling

The Metropolis algorithm works whenever the probability of proposing a jump to B from A is equal to the probability of proposing A from B, when the proposal distribution is symmetric. There is a more general method, known as Metropolis-Hastings, that allows asymmetric proposals. 

An algorithm that allows asymmetric proposals is useful because:

- it makes it easier to handle parameters, like standard deviations, that have boundaries at zero

- we can acquire an equally good image of the posterior distribution in fewer steps

Gibbs sampling is a variant of the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm that uses clever proposals and is therefore more efficient&mdash; you can get a good estimate of the posterior from Gibbs sampling with many fewer samples than a comparable Metropolis approach. The improvement arises from ***adaptive proposals*** in which the distribution of proposed parameter values adjusts itself intelligently, depending upon the parameter values at the moment. Gibbs sampling computes these adaptive proposals using particular combinations of prior distributions and likelihoods known as *conjugate pairs*.

Some limitations of Gibbs sampling:

- Some conjugate priors seem silly, and choosing a prior so that the model fits efficiently isn’t really a strong argument from a scientific perspective.

- As models become more complex and contain hundreds or thousands or tens of thousands of parameters, Gibbs sampling becomes shockingly inefficient.

<br>

### Hamiltonian Monte Carlo

Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (or Hybrid Monte Carlo, HMC) adopts Jaynes’ principle that, *"whenever there is a randomized way of doing something, then there is a non-randomized way that delivers better performance but requires more thought."*

HMC is much more computationally costly than are Metropolis or Gibbs sampling&mdash; both highly random procedures. But its proposals are typically much more efficient&mdash; doesn’t need as many samples to describe the posterior distribution, outshine other algorithms as models become more complex (thousands or tens of thousands of parameters). HMC outperforms Metropolis and Gibbs sampling, but it is not a universal solution to all MCMC problems.

Monty’s kingdom is not a discrete set of islands. Instead, it is a continuous territory stretched out along a narrow valley. Monty's advisor, Hamilton realized that a much more efficient way to visit the citizens in the continuous Kingdom is to travel back and forth along its length. In order to spend more time in densely settled areas, they should slow the royal vehicle down when houses grow more dense. Likewise, they should speed up when houses grow more sparse. This strategy requires knowing how quickly population density is changing, at their current location. But it doesn’t require remembering where they’ve been or knowing the population distribution anyplace else. And a major benefit of this strategy compared to that of Metropolis is that the King makes a full sweep of the kingdom before revisiting anyone.

In statistical applications, the royal vehicle is the current vector of parameter values. Let’s consider the single parameter case, just to keep things simple. In that case, the log-posterior is like a bowl, with the MAP at its nadir. Then the job is to sweep across the surface of the bowl, adjusting speed in proportion to how high up we are. In cases where ordinary Metropolis or Gibbs sampling wander slowly through parameter space, Hamiltonian Monte Carlo remains efficient.

Some limitations of HMC:

- HMC requires continuous parameters. It can’t glide through a discrete parameter. 

- it needs to be tuned to a particular model and its data. That’s where an engine like Stan (mc-stan.org) comes in. Stan automates much of that tuning.

<br>

## Easy HMC: `map2stan`

`map2stan` compiles lists of formulas, like the lists you’ve been using so far to construct map estimates, into Stan HMC code. To use `map2stan`, you need to preprocess any variable transformations, and you need to construct a clean data frame with only the variables you will use.

```{r 8.2}

# load the data and reduce it down to cases (nations) that have the outcome variable of interest
data(rugged)
d <- rugged
d$log_gdp <- log(d$rgdppc_2000)
dd <- d[ complete.cases(d$rgdppc_2000) , ]

# Fit the interaction model which  aims to predict log-GDP with terrain ruggedness, 
# continent, and the interaction of the two
m8.1 <- rethinking::map(
    alist(
        log_gdp ~ dnorm( mu , sigma ) ,
        mu <- a + bR*rugged + bA*cont_africa + bAR*rugged*cont_africa ,
        a ~ dnorm(0,100),
        bR ~ dnorm(0,10),
        bA ~ dnorm(0,10),
        bAR ~ dnorm(0,10),
        sigma ~ dunif(0,10)
),
    data=dd )
precis(m8.1)

```

<br>

### Preparation

But now we’ll also fit this model using Hamiltonian Monte Carlo. This means there will be no more quadratic approximation&mdash; if the posterior distribution is non-Gaussian, then we’ll get whatever non-Gaussian shape it has. You can use exactly the same formula list as before, but you need to do two additional things.

(1) Preprocess all variable transformations.

      - If the outcome is transformed somehow, like by taking the logarithm, then do this before fitting the model by constructing a new variable in the data frame. 
        
      - Likewise, if any predictor variables are transformed, including squaring and cubing and such to build polynomial models, then compute these transformed values before fitting the model.
        
\n

(2) Once you’ve got all the variables ready, make a new trimmed down data frame that contains only the variables you will actually use to fit the model. Technically, you don’t have to do this. But doing so avoids common problems. For example, if any of the unused variables have missing values, NA, then Stan will refuse to work.

```{r 8.4}

dd.trim <- dd[ , c("log_gdp","rugged","cont_africa") ]
str(dd.trim)

# The data frame dd.trim contains only the three variables we’re using.
```

<br>

### Estimation

```{r 8.5}

## Use akjurz's codes (ulam stops working today, so I changed all ulam codes, so doc render)
# Get samples from the posterior distribution using HMC
output <- capture.output(b8.1 <-
  brm(data = dd, family = gaussian,
      log_gdp ~ 1 + rugged + cont_africa + rugged:cont_africa,
      prior = c(prior(normal(0, 100), class = Intercept),
                prior(normal(0, 10), class = b),
                prior(cauchy(0, 2), class = sigma)),
      seed = 8)) # a weakly regularizing prior for standard deviations

# The uniform prior on sigma has been changed to a half-Cauchy prior. (cauchy)
# The Cauchy distribution is a useful thick-tailed probability distribution 
# related to the Student t distribution.

print(b8.1)
## The brms::brm() function defaults to chains = 4. It also defaults to cores = 1, 
## iter = 2000, warmup = 1000. 
## McElreath’s rethinking::precis() returns highest posterior density intervals (HPDIs) 
## when summarizing map2stan() models. Not so with brms. If you want HPDIs, 
## you’ll have to use the convenience functions from the tidybayes package.

# library(tidybayes)

post <- posterior_samples(b8.1)

post %>% 
  gather() %>% 
  group_by(key) %>% 
  mean_hdi(value, .width = .89)


# The interval boundaries in the table are highest posterior density intervals (HPDI), 
# not ordinary percentile intervals (PI).

# n_eff and Rhat provide MCMC diagnostic criteria, to help you tell how well estimation worked.
# n_eff is a crude estimate of the number of independent samples you managed to get.
# Rhat is a complicated estimate of the convergence of the Markov chains to the target 
# distribution. It should approach 1.00 from above, when all is well.

```

<br>

### Sampling agian, in parallel

Once you have compiled your Stan model, you can draw more samples from it anytime, running as many independent Markov chains as you like. And you can easily parallelize those chains, as well. To run four independent Markov chains for the model above, and to distribute them across separate processors in your computer, just pass the previous fit back to map2stan:

```{r 8.7, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
## Here we sample in parallel by adding cores = 4.
output <- capture.output(b8.1_4chains_4cores <- update(b8.1, 
         cores = 4))

## This model sampled so fast that it really didn’t matter if we sampled in 
## parallel or not. It will for others.
print(b8.1_4chains_4cores)
```

<br>

### Visualization

```{r 8.8}

## Unlike the way rethinking’s extract.samples() yields a list, 
## brms’s posterior_samples() returns a data frame.
post <- posterior_samples(b8.1)
str(post)

## As with McElreath’s rethinking, brms allows users to put the post data frame 
## or the brmsfit object directly in pairs().

# To plot all these samples at once, provided there aren’t too many parameters
pairs(b8.1,
      off_diag_args = list(size = 1/5, alpha = 1/5))
# Pairs plot of the samples produced by Stan. The diagonal shows a density estimate for 
# each parameter. Below the diagonal, correlations between parameters are shown.

```

<br>

### Using the samples

If you have the samples from the posterior and you know the model, you can do anything: simulate predictions, compute differences between parameters, and calculate DIC and WAIC.

```{r 8.11}

## Use brms (copy Akjurz's codes)
# Run HMC model
output <- capture.output(b8.1 <-
  brm(data = dd, family = gaussian,
      log_gdp ~ 1 + rugged + cont_africa + rugged:cont_africa,
      prior = c(prior(normal(0, 100), class = Intercept),
                prior(normal(0, 10), class = b),
                prior(cauchy(0, 2), class = sigma)),
      seed = 8))

print(b8.1)

# Calculate waic
waic(b8.1)

# use loo (leave-one-out) cross-validation
(l_b8.1 <- loo(b8.1))

# And the recommended workflow since brms version 2.8.0 is to save the information 
# criteria information with your brm() fit objects with the add_criterion() function.
b8.1 <- add_criterion(b8.1, c("waic", "loo"))

# retrieve information 
b8.1$waic
b8.1$loo

```

<br>

### Checking the chain 

A trace plot&mdash; the most broadly useful tool for diagnosing malfunction&mdash; merely plots the samples in sequential order, joined by a line. Looking at the trace plot of each parameter can help to diagnose many common problems. A trace plot isn’t the last thing analysts do to inspect MCMC output. But it’s nearly always the first.

```{r 8.12}

# In the terrain ruggedness example, the trace plot shows a very healthy chain.
plot(b8.1) # m8.1stan doesn't work

## Use akjurz's codes to do trace plots
p1 <-
  as_draws_df(b8.1) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(0:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

(
  (p1) &
    scale_color_ipsum() &
    theme(legend.position = "right")
)

post <- posterior_samples(b8.1, add_chain = T)

# This is a clean, healthy Markov chain, both stationary and well-mixing.


# The bayesplot package offers a variety of diagnostic plots. Here we make 
# autocorrelation plots for all model parameters, one for each HMC chain.
mcmc_acf(post, 
         pars = c("b_Intercept", "b_rugged", "b_cont_africa", 
                  "b_rugged:cont_africa", "sigma"),
         lags = 5) +
  scale_color_ipsum() +
  theme_ipsum()
# That’s just what we like to see–nice L-shaped autocorrelation plots. Those are 
# the kinds of shapes you’d expect when you have reasonably large effective samples.
## Only one chain is displayed here and Ip_ (is that a graph for prior?) shouldn't be showing.

```

Typically we look for two things in these trace plots: stationarity and good mixing. Stationarity refers to the path staying within the posterior distribution. Notice that these traces, for example, all stick around a very stable central tendency, the center of gravity of each dimension of the posterior. Another way to think of this is that the mean value of the chain is quite stable from beginning to end.

A well-mixing chain means that each successive sample within each parameter is not highly correlated with the sample before it. Visually, you can see this by the rapid zig-zag motion of each path, as the trace traverses the posterior distribution without getting mired anyplace.

<br>

<span style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Raw stan model code**</span>

```{r model_block, eval=FALSE, echo=TRUE}

## Stan code
# It is essentially the formula list you provided to map2stan, but in reverse order. 
# The first line, vector[N] mu; names a symbol to hold the linear model. The rest of 
# the code reiterates your formulas, beginning with priors and then computing the 
# value of mu for each observation (nation). Finally, the last line comprises the 
# likelihood. Given this kind of model definition, Stan will define and sample from 
# the HMC chain or chains you ask for.
model{
    vector[N] mu;
    sigma ~ cauchy( 0 , 2 );
    bAR ~ normal( 0 , 10 );
    bA ~ normal( 0 , 10 );
    bR ~ normal( 0 , 10 );
   a ~ normal( 0 , 100 );
    for ( i in 1:N ) {
        mu[i] <- a + bR * rugged[i] + bA * cont_africa[i] +
                 bAR * rugged[i] * cont_africa[i];
}
    log_gdp ~ normal( mu , sigma );
}

```

```{r akjurz}

# The stancode() function works in brms much like it does in rethinking.
brms::stancode(b8.1)

# You can also get that information with b8.1$model or b8.1$fit@stanmodel.
# b8.1$model
# b8.1$fit@stanmodel

```

<br>

## Care and feeding of your Markov chain 

### How many samples do you need?

You can control the number of samples from the chain by using the `iter` and `warmup` parameters. The defaults are 2000 for `iter` and `warmup` is set to `iter`/2, which gives you 1000 `warmup` samples and 1000 real samples to use for inference. But these defaults are just meant to get you started, to make sure the chain gets started okay. Then you can decide on other values for `iter` and `warmup`.

So how many samples do we need for accurate inference about the posterior distribution? It depends. First, what really matters is the effective number of samples, not the raw number. The effective number of samples is an estimate of the number of independent samples from the posterior distribution. Markov chains are typically autocorrelated, so that sequential samples are not entirely independent. Stan chains tend to be less autocorrelated than those produced by other engines, but there is always some autocorrelation. Stan provides an estimate of effective number of samples as `n_eff`.

Second, what do you want to know? If all you want are posterior means, it doesn’t take many samples at all to get very good estimates. Even a couple hundred samples will do. But if you care about the exact shape in the extreme tails of the posterior, the 99th percentile or so, then you’ll need many many more. So there is no universally useful number of samples to aim for.

The `warmup` setting is more subtle. On the one hand, you want to have the shortest `warmup` period necessary, so you can get on with real sampling. But on the other hand, more `warmup` can mean more efficient sampling. With Stan models, typically you can devote as much as half of your total samples, the `iter` value, to `warmup` and come out very well. But for simple models like those you’ve fit so far, much less `warmup` is really needed. Models can vary a lot in the shape of their posterior distributions, so again there is no universally best answer. But if you are having trouble, you might try increasing the `warmup`. If not, you might try reducing it.

<br>

### How many chains do you need?

- When debugging a model, use a single chain. 

- When deciding whether the chains are valid, you need more than one chain. 
    - Using 3 or 4 chains is conventional, and quite often more than enough to reassure us that the sampling is working properly.
    
\n

- When you begin the final run that you’ll make inferences from, you only really need one chain. But using more than one chain is fine, as well. It just doesn’t matter, once you’re sure it’s working.
    - More chains cost you an extra samples of `warmup` that just get thrown away. And since warmup is typically the slowest part of the chain, these extra samples cost a disproportionate amount of your computer’s time.
    - On the other hand, if you run the chains on different computers or processor cores within a single computer, then you might prefer more chains, because you can spread the load and finish the whole job faster.
    
\n

*For typical regression models, you can live by the motto four short chains to check, one long chain for inference.* (Things may still go wrong) 

<br>

<span style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Convergence diagnostics**</span>

- The default diagnostic output from Stan includes two metrics, `n_eff` and `Rhat`. 
    - `n_eff` is a measure of the effective number of samples. 
        - When `n_eff`is much lower than the actual number of iterations (minus warmup) of your chains, it means the chains are inefficient, but possibly still okay. 
    - `Rhat` is the Gelman-Rubin convergence diagnostic, <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\hat{R}}" title="" />. 
        -  When Rhat is above 1.00, it usually indicates that the chain has not yet converged, and probably you shouldn’t trust the samples. If you draw more iterations, it could be fine, or it could never converge. For example, Rhat can reach 1.00 even for an invalid chain. So view it perhaps as a signal of danger, but never of safety. For conventional models, these metrics typically work well.

<br>

### Taming a wild chain

One common problem with some models is that there are broad, flat regions of the posterior density. This happens most often, as you might guess, when one uses flat priors. The problem this can generate is a wild, wandering Markov chain that erratically samples extremely positive and extremely negative parameter values.

<br>

```{r akjurz_8.13}

## Use akjurz's codes using brms
# As with rethinking, brms can take data in the form of a list. Recall however, 
# that in order to specify starting values, you need to specify a list of lists 
# with an inits argument rather than with start.
output <- capture.output(b8.2 <-
  brm(data = list(y = c(-1, 1)), 
      family = gaussian,
      y ~ 1,
      prior = c(prior(uniform(-1e10, 1e10), class = Intercept),
                prior(uniform(0, 1e10), class = sigma)),
      inits = list(list(Intercept = 0, sigma = 1),
                   list(Intercept = 0, sigma = 1)),
      iter = 4000, warmup = 1000, chains = 2,
      seed = 8))

# Those were some silly flat priors. Check the damage.
 p1 <-
  as_draws_df(b8.2) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(0:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

print(b8.2)
# Ludicrous numbers, super wide CI and Rhat is higher than 1 (1.23)

## With reasonable priors
output <- capture.output(b8.3 <-
  brm(data = list(y = c(-1, 1)), 
      family = gaussian,
      y ~ 1,
      prior = c(prior(normal(0, 10), class = Intercept),
                prior(cauchy(0, 1), class = sigma)),
      inits = list(list(Intercept = 0, sigma = 1),
                   list(Intercept = 0, sigma = 1)),
      iter = 4000, warmup = 1000, chains = 2,
      seed = 8))

print(b8.3)

# Generate trace plots
 p2 <-
  as_draws_df(b8.3) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(0:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

(
  (p1/p2) &
    scale_color_ipsum() &
    theme(legend.position = "right")
) 
# Diagnosing and healing a sick Markov chain. 
# Top row: Trace plot from two independent chains defined by model b8.2. These chains 
# are not stationary and should not be used for inference. 
# Bottom row: Adding weakly informative priors (see b8.3) clears up the condition right away. 
# These chains are fine to use for inference.

# Compare posterior and priors for model b8.3
post <- as_draws_df(b8.3)
#post %>%
  #select(b_Intercept) %>%
 d1 <- ggplot(post, aes(x = b_Intercept)) +
  stat_density(geom = "line") +
  geom_line(data = data.frame(x = seq(from = min(post$b_Intercept),
                                      to = max(post$b_Intercept),
                                      length.out = 50)),
            aes(x = x, y = dnorm(x = x, mean = 0, sd = 10)),
            color = ipsum_pal()(1), linetype = 2) +
  theme_ipsum()

# post %>%
#  select(sigma) %>%
  
 d2 <- ggplot(post, aes(x = sigma)) +
  stat_density(geom = "line") +
  geom_line(data = data.frame(x = seq(from = 0,
                                      to = max(post$sigma),
                                      length.out = 50)),
            aes(x = x, y = dcauchy(x = x, location = 0, scale = 1)*2),
            color = ipsum_pal()(2)[2], linetype = 2) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 10)) +
  theme_ipsum()
  
 grid.arrange(d1, d2, ncol = 2)
 
# Prior (dashed) and posterior (solid black) for the model with weakly informative priors.
# Even with only two observations, the likelihood easily overcomes these priors. 
# Yet the model cannot be successfully estimated without them.


```

<br>

<span style="color:brown"><span style="text-decoration:underline">**Cauchy distribution**</span>

-  The Cauchy (ko-shee) distribution gives the distribution of the ratio of two random Gaussian draws.  
        - Its parameters are a location <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{x_0}" title="" /> and a scale <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\gamma}" title="" />. The location says where the center is, and the scale defines how stretched out the distribution is. 
        - Cauchy has no defined mean nor variance, so the location and scale are not its mean and standard deviation. The reason the Cauchy has no mean and variance is that it is a very thick-tailed distribution. At any moment in a Cauchy sampling process, it is possible to draw an extreme value that overwhelms all of the previous draws. The consequence of this fact is that the sequence never converges to a stable mean and variance. It just keeps moving.
        
\n

- Half-Cauchy is a Cauchy defined over the positive reals only. This is because they are applied to a parameter, usually <img src="https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?\boldsymbol{\sigma}" title="" />, that is strictly positive.

```{r 8.16}
# The code below samples 10,000 values from a Cauchy distribution. 
# Then it computes and plots the running mean at each sample. 
# Run this simulation a few times to see how the trace of the mean is highly unpredictable.

y <- rcauchy(1e4,0,5)
mu <- sapply( 1:length(y) , function(i) sum(y[1:i])/i )
plot(mu,type="l")
# The distribution of mu changes significantly with each run. 
```

<br>

### Non-identifiable parameters

The non-identifiable parameters (created by higly correlated predictors) can be identified by using a little prior information.

```{r 8.17, fig.height=5}

# To construct a non-identifiable model, we first simulate 100 observations from 
# a Gaussian distribution with mean zero and standard deviation 1.
y <- rnorm( 100 , mean=0 , sd=1 )

# Fit the model (use akjurz's codes)
output <- capture.output(b8.4 <-
  brm(data = list(y           = y,
                  intercept_1 = 1,
                  intercept_2 = 1), 
      family = gaussian,
      y ~ 0 + intercept_1 + intercept_2,
      prior = c(prior(uniform(-1e10, 1e10), class = b),
                prior(cauchy(0, 1), class = sigma)),
      inits = list(list(intercept_1 = 0, intercept_2 = 0, sigma = 1),
                   list(intercept_1 = 0, intercept_2 = 0, sigma = 1)),
      iter = 4000, warmup = 1000, chains = 2,
      seed = 8))

print(b8.4)
# The estimates look suspicious, and the n_eff and Rhat values are terrible. 
# The means for a1 and a2 are almost exactly the same distance from zero, 
# but on opposite sides. And the standard deviations of the chains are massive. 
# This is of course a result of the fact that we cannot simultaneously estimate 
# a1 and a2, but only their sum.

## Use weak priors
output <- capture.output(b8.5 <-
  brm(data = list(y           = y,
                  intercept_1 = 1,
                  intercept_2 = 1),
      family = gaussian,
      y ~ 0 + intercept_1 + intercept_2,
      prior = c(prior(normal(0, 10), class = b),
                prior(cauchy(0, 1), class = sigma)),
      inits = list(list(intercept_1 = 0, intercept_2 = 0, sigma = 1),
                   list(intercept_1 = 0, intercept_2 = 0, sigma = 1)),
      iter = 4000, warmup = 1000, chains = 2,
      seed = 8))

print(b8.5)
# The estimates for a1 and a2 are better identified now.

# Combine trace plots

  p1 <-
  as_draws_df(b8.4) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(0:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

p2 <-
  as_draws_df(b8.5) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(0:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

(
  (p1 / p2) &
    scale_color_ipsum() &
    theme(legend.position = "right")
)

## Top row: A chain with wandering parameters, b8.4. 
## Bottom row: Same model but now with weakly informative priors, b8.5.
# With flat priors sampling may take 8 times as long as it does for model with weak priors. 
# Often, a model that is very slow to sample is under-identified. This is an aspect of the 
# `folk theorem of statistical computing`: When you are having trouble fitting a model, 
# it often indicates a bad model.

```

<br>

## Practice

### Easy

> 8E1. Which of the following is a requirement of the simple Metropolis algorithm?

(3) The proposal distribution must be symmetric.

<br>

> 8E2. Gibbs sampling is more efficient than the Metropolis algorithm. How does it achieve this extra
efficiency? Are there any limitations to the Gibbs sampling strategy?

Gibbs sampling allows asymmetric proposal distributions, making handling of parameters easier and requiring fewer steps (and samples) to generate a good estimate of posterior distribution. 

Gibbs sampling is inefficient for complex models with many parameters, and it requires combinations of priors and likelihoods known as conjugate pairs. 

<br>

> 8E3. Which sort of parameters can Hamiltonian Monte Carlo not handle? Can you explain why?

Hamiltonian Monte Caro cannot handle discrete parameters as it requires continuous parameters to glide through the log-posterior smoothly, and it makes use of differential equations that apply to continuous variables. 

<br>

> 8E4. Explain the difference between the effective number of samples, n_eff as calculated by Stan, and the actual number of samples.

The effective number of samples is an estimate of the number of independent samples from the posterior distribution that would provide similar information as the actual number of samples generated by simulations. 


<br>

> 8E5. Which value should Rhat approach, when a chain is sampling the posterior distribution correctly?

One.


<br>

> 8E6. Sketch a good trace plot for a Markov chain, one that is effectively sampling from the posterior distribution. What is good about its shape? Then sketch a trace plot for a malfunctioning Markov chain. What about its shape indicates malfunction?


```{r 8E6}

output <- capture.output(goodplot <-
  brm(data = list(y = c(-1, 1)), 
      family = gaussian,
      y ~ 1,
      prior = c(prior(uniform(0, 10), class = Intercept),
                prior(uniform(0, 10), class = sigma)),
      inits = list(list(Intercept = 0, sigma = 1),
                   list(Intercept = 0, sigma = 1)),
      iter = 4000, warmup = 1000, chains = 2,
      seed = 8))

output <- capture.output(badplot <-
  brm(data = list(y = c(-1, 1)), 
      family = gaussian,
      y ~ 1,
      prior = c(prior(uniform(-1e20, 1e20), class = Intercept),
                prior(uniform(0, 1e20), class = sigma)),
      inits = list(list(Intercept = 0, sigma = 1),
                   list(Intercept = 0, sigma = 1)),
      iter = 4000, warmup = 1000, chains = 2,
      seed = 8))
p1 <-
  as_draws_df(goodplot) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(b_Intercept:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

p2 <-
  as_draws_df(badplot) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(b_Intercept:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

(
  (p1 / p2) &
    scale_color_ipsum() &
    theme(legend.position = "right")
) +
  plot_annotation(subtitle = "Good trace plot (Top) and Bad trace plot (Bottom)")
```

The chains in good trace plot for a Markov chain (top row) are stationary and well-mixing, whereas the chains in the bad trace plot (bottom) are not converging to posterior distribution&mdash; chain 1 wanders off to extreme values and chain 2 is completely flat. 

<br>

### Medium

> 8M1. Re-estimate the terrain ruggedness model from the chapter, but now using a uniform prior and an exponential prior for the standard deviation, sigma. The uniform prior should be dunif(0,10) and the exponential should be dexp(1). Do the different priors have any detectible influence on the posterior distribution?

```{r 8M1}

# Load data
data("rugged")
d <- rugged

# make log version of outcome
d$log_gdp <- log( d$rgdppc_2000 )

# extract countries with GDP data
dd <- d[ complete.cases(d$rgdppc_2000) , ]

output <- capture.output(uniform <-
  brm(data = dd, family = gaussian,
      log_gdp ~ 1 + rugged + cont_africa + rugged:cont_africa,
      prior = c(prior(normal(0, 100), class = Intercept),
                prior(normal(0, 10), class = b),
                prior(uniform(0, 10), class = sigma)),
      seed = 8))

print(uniform)

output <- capture.output(exponential <-
  brm(data = dd, family = gaussian,
      log_gdp ~ 1 + rugged + cont_africa + rugged:cont_africa,
      prior = c(prior(normal(0, 100), class = Intercept),
                prior(normal(0, 10), class = b),
                prior(exponential(1), class = sigma)),
      seed = 8))

print(exponential)

p1 <-
  as_draws_df(uniform) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(b_Intercept:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

p2 <-
  as_draws_df(exponential) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(b_Intercept:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

(
  (p1 / p2) &
    scale_color_ipsum() &
    theme(legend.position = "right")
)




```

<br>


```{r 8M1c}

# Sigmas for priors
curve( dcauchy(x,0,2) , from=0 , to=10 ,
    xlab="sigma" , ylab="Density" , ylim=c(0,1),  
    main = "Comparison of Sigmas for Prior Distributions" )
curve( dunif(x,0,10) , add=TRUE , col="red" )
curve( dexp(x,1) , add=TRUE , col="blue" )
legend("topright", legend = c("Cauchy (scale = 2)", 
                              "Cauchy (scale = 10)", "Exponential (rate = 1)"), 
       col = c("black", "red", "blue"), lty = 1)

# Compare sigmas for posterior distribution
sigma_o <- as_draws_df(b8.1)
sigma_u <- as_draws_df(uniform)
sigma_e <- as_draws_df(exponential)

dens( sigma_o[[5]] , xlab="sigma" , xlim=c(0.5,1.5), ylim=c(0,8),
      main = "Comparison of Sigmas for Posterior Distributions")
dens( sigma_u[[5]] , add=TRUE , col = "red" )
dens( sigma_e[[5]] , add=TRUE , col = "blue" )
legend("topright", legend = c("Cauchy (scale = 2)", "Cauchy (scale = 10)", 
                              "Exponential (rate = 1)"), 
       col = c("black", "red", "blue"), lty = 1)

```


I used `uniform` and `exponential` instead of `dunif` and `dexp`, since I'm using `brms`. The different priors do not have any detectable influence on the posterior distribution, as seen in the `print` results and figures.

<br>

<span style="color:gray">***Given answer:***</span> 

All three posterior distributions are very similar. Why? There’s a lot of data, relative to the difference in priors.

<br>

> 8M2. The Cauchy and exponential priors from the terrain ruggedness model are very weak. They can be made more informative by reducing their scale. Compare the dcauchy and dexp priors for progressively smaller values of the scaling parameter. As these priors become stronger, how does each influence the posterior distribution?

```{r 8M2, fig.height=8}

# Original
output <- capture.output(b8.1 <-
  brm(data = dd, family = gaussian,
      log_gdp ~ 1 + rugged + cont_africa + rugged:cont_africa,
      prior = c(prior(normal(0, 100), class = Intercept),
                prior(normal(0, 10), class = b),
                prior(cauchy(0, 2), class = sigma)),
      seed = 8))

print(b8.1)

# Stronger prior with cauchy
output <- capture.output(uniform1 <-
  brm(data = dd, family = gaussian,
      log_gdp ~ 1 + rugged + cont_africa + rugged:cont_africa,
      prior = c(prior(normal(0, 100), class = Intercept),
                prior(normal(0, 10), class = b),
                prior(cauchy(0, 1), class = sigma)), # weaker prior with bigger sd
      seed = 8))

print(uniform1)

# Stronger prior with exponential
output <- capture.output(exponential2 <-
  brm(data = dd, family = gaussian,
      log_gdp ~ 1 + rugged + cont_africa + rugged:cont_africa,
      prior = c(prior(normal(0, 100), class = Intercept),
                prior(normal(0, 10), class = b),
                prior(exponential(10), class = sigma)), # stronger prior with bigger expo
      seed = 8))

print(exponential2)

p1 <-
  as_draws_df(b8.1) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(b_Intercept:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

p2 <-
  as_draws_df(uniform1) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(b_Intercept:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

p3 <-
  as_draws_df(exponential2) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(b_Intercept:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

(
  (p1 / p2/ p3) &
    scale_color_ipsum() &
    theme(legend.position = "right")
)

```

<br>

```{r c8v}

# Sigmas for priors
curve( dcauchy(x,0,2) , from=0 , to=10 ,
    xlab="sigma" , ylab="Density" , ylim=c(0,1),  
    main = "Comparison of Sigmas for Prior Distributions" )
curve( dcauchy(x,0,1) , add=TRUE , col="red" )
curve( dexp(x,10) , add=TRUE , col="blue" )
legend("topright", legend = c("Cauchy (scale = 2)", 
                              "Cauchy (scale = 1)", "Exponential (rate = 2)"), 
       col = c("black", "red", "blue"), lty = 1)

# Compare sigmas for posterior distribution
sigma <- as_draws_df(b8.1)
sigma_1 <- as_draws_df(uniform1)
sigma_2 <- as_draws_df(exponential2)

dens( sigma[[5]] , xlab="sigma" , xlim=c(0.5,1.5), ylim=c(0,10),
      main = "Comparison of Sigmas for Posterior Distributions")
dens( sigma_1[[5]] , add=TRUE , col = "red" )
dens( sigma_2[[5]] , add=TRUE , col = "blue" )
legend("topright", legend = c("Cauchy (scale = 2)", "Cauchy (scale = 1)", 
                              "Exponential (rate = 10)"), 
       col = c("black", "red", "blue"), lty = 1)

```

Not very different with slightly stronger priors. Set much stronger prior for exponential:

```{r 8M2.1, fig.height=8}

# Original
output <- capture.output(b8.1 <-
  brm(data = dd, family = gaussian,
      log_gdp ~ 1 + rugged + cont_africa + rugged:cont_africa,
      prior = c(prior(normal(0, 100), class = Intercept),
                prior(normal(0, 10), class = b),
                prior(cauchy(0, 2), class = sigma)),
      seed = 8))

print(b8.1)

# Stronger prior with cauchy

output <- capture.output(uniform_new <-
  brm(data = dd, family = gaussian,
      log_gdp ~ 1 + rugged + cont_africa + rugged:cont_africa,
      prior = c(prior(normal(0, 100), class = Intercept),
                prior(normal(0, 10), class = b),
                prior(cauchy(0, 0.1), class = sigma)), 
      seed = 8))

print(uniform_new)

output <- capture.output(exponential_new <-
  brm(data = dd, family = gaussian,
      log_gdp ~ 1 + rugged + cont_africa + rugged:cont_africa,
      prior = c(prior(normal(0, 100), class = Intercept),
                prior(normal(0, 10), class = b),
                prior(exponential(100), class = sigma)),
      seed = 8))

print(exponential_new)

p1 <-
  as_draws_df(b8.1) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(b_Intercept:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

p2 <-
  as_draws_df(uniform_new) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(b_Intercept:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

p3 <-
  as_draws_df(exponential_new) %>% 
  mcmc_trace(pars = vars(b_Intercept:sigma),
             linewidth = 0.25)

(
  (p1 / p2 / p3) &
    scale_color_ipsum() &
    theme(legend.position = "right")
)

```

<br>

```{r curv1}
# Sigmas for priors
curve( dcauchy(x,0,2) , from=0 , to=10 ,
    xlab="sigma" , ylab="Density" , ylim=c(0,1),  
    main = "Comparison of Sigmas for Prior Distributions" )
curve( dcauchy(x,0,0.1) , add=TRUE , col="red" )
curve( dexp(x,100) , add=TRUE , col="blue" )
legend("topright", legend = c("Cauchy (scale = 2)", 
                              "Cauchy (scale = 0.1)", "Exponential (rate = 100)"), 
       col = c("black", "red", "blue"), lty = 1)

# Compare sigmas for posterior distribution
sigma_original <- as_draws_df(b8.1)
sigma_uniform <- as_draws_df(uniform_new)
sigma_exponential <- as_draws_df(exponential_new)

dens( sigma_original[[5]] , xlab="sigma" , xlim=c(0.5,1.5), ylim=c(0,13),
      main = "Comparison of Sigmas for Posterior Distributions")
dens( sigma_uniform[[5]] , add=TRUE , col = "red" )
dens( sigma_exponential[[5]] , add=TRUE , col = "blue" )
legend("topright", legend = c("Cauchy (scale = 2)", "Cauchy (scale = 0.1)", 
                              "Exponential (rate = 100)"), 
       col = c("black", "red", "blue"), lty = 1)

```


<br>

> 8M3. Re-estimate one of the Stan models from the chapter, but at different numbers of warmup iterations. Be sure to use the same number of sampling iterations in each case. Compare the n_eff values. How much warmup is enough?

```{r 8M3}

# Function to fit model and calculate effective sample size
fit.model.function <- function(warmup) {
  # Fit the model
  output <- capture.output(model <- brm(data = list(y = c(-1, 1)), 
               family = gaussian,
               y ~ 1,
               prior = c(prior(normal(0, 10), class = Intercept),
                         prior(cauchy(0, 1), class = sigma)),
               inits = list(list(Intercept = 0, sigma = 1),
                            list(Intercept = 0, sigma = 1)),
               iter = 4000, warmup = warmup, chains = 2,
               seed = 8))
  
  # Extract MCMC samples
  mcmc_samples <- as.mcmc(model)
  
  # Calculate effective sample size
  ess <- effectiveSize(mcmc_samples)
  
  return(ess)
}

# List of warm-up values
warmup_values <- c(1, 5, 10, 100, 500, 1000)

# Loop through each warm-up value and fit the model
output <- capture.output(ess_values <- sapply(warmup_values, function(warmup) {
  fit.model.function(warmup)
}))

ess_values

## A warmup value of 5 is enough for this model. 

```

<br>
